name: Hill, Sen Robert
text:
—I am quite happy to talk for some time on the subject of forestry, because it is an important issue and it should be clarified. The government has taken the view that the process of regional forest agreements is outside of this legislation because they have been in themselves a most comprehensive process—I think one can fairly say the most comprehensive assessment of Australian forests in our national history. The government chose to take that course of action—which, I concede, was to adopt a national strategy that had been negotiated between the previous Labor government and the states—because it, for the first time, set out a framework within which there could be some certainty for forest industries but with a background of protecting a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system and also to ensure that the forestry that was to take place in relation to native forests, on the balance—that is, that which is outside the comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system—had to be conducted in both an ecologically and economically sustainable way.
The precedent of that structure is regarded as world best practice. I can recall two years ago, for example, attending a CSD meeting in 
 New York when WWF International held up the Australian precedent as the example that they would like to be achieved globally, because the reserve system was of course of a higher composition than the recommendations that they were putting down internationally. Also just as important is to ensure that the forest that is to be harvested is harvested, as I said, not only in an economic way—which is what has been considered in the past—but also in an ecologically sustainable way.
We went about the task of conducting those assessments. I would be the first to acknowledge just how difficult that process has been. Nevertheless, those RFAs that have been agreed—the RFA for Tasmania, the RFA in Western Australia and two RFAs in Victoria, in Central Highlands and East Gippsland—I think have achieved the goals that Labor actually had set down for us in the National Forest Strategy. I am pleased to say that we are very close to completion of the agreement for the Eden region in New South Wales. We are close to another agreement in Victoria. We are finally making some progress on the balance of regions in New South Wales and with regard to the Queensland proposal. Whilst it has been politically difficult and it has been difficult in practice to implement, we are achieving those goals.
After such a comprehensive assessment as that it makes no sense, to the government in any event, to then come back through this legislation and seek to achieve another path for assessment. That is why we have chosen to take the course of action of leaving the RFAs outside of the bill as such. I can see that there are others in the chamber who would argue that that is not the best course of action to have taken. We have a difference of view in this particular matter, but that is the basis on which we have taken this action.
I make the point because I want to demonstrate, in case it is misrepresented by some, such as Senator Brown, as an attempt to avoid the responsibility for assessment and for making proper decisions in relation to natural forests, that it is quite the contrary. It is in recognition that there has been a parallel process of a comprehensive nature to carry 
 out those assessments and to achieve the best possible outcomes both environmentally and economically. That is the reason we have moved in this direction.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—Here we get to the heart of this terrible business. The minister has just tried to say that the forests are outside of this legislation. If any honourable senators turn to pages 40 and 41, they will see that division 4 is given over to forestry operations. I want you to remember, Chair, throughout my delivery in the next 15 minutes, that everything I refer to here has changed since last week. Last week the Democrats were the defenders of the environment and the forests. Now they have become not only part of the problem but also the pivotal vote in cementing into place the destruction of forests around this country for the next 20 years.
I read earlier from a letter from world noted scientist Dr Aila Keto of the Australian Rainforest Conservation Society, who is also representing another dozen conservation groups in Queensland. In this heartfelt letter that she sent to Senator Lees yesterday, the fourth paragraph reads:
The legislation will entrench Regional Forest Agreements, locking in ongoing threats that have put so many forests and their wildlife on the brink of extinction, and it will be nearly impossible or too late to do anything about it for the next 20 years.
In that 20 years, under this Democrat approved process, more than one million hectares of Australia's wild forests, ancient ecosystems and wildlife—the bird life, the possums, the bats, the insects, and the fish and the platypuses in the rivers draining from those places—will be threatened with extinction because of this dark Democrat deed being done today. This legislation would not be going through—this imprimatur of the Democrats on the regional forest agreements, as laid out in this legislation—except for their going to the Howard table last week to gain a little bit of power and, in the process, as entry to that table, dropping all of their past principles. Let me read from section 39 on page 40:
The purpose of this Subdivision— 

Chair, you will understand if I interpret this now by saying that it is the purpose of this now Democrat approved subdivision—
is to ensure that an approval—
that is, a ministerial approval before something dastardly is done to the environment—
under Part 9 is not required for forestry operations in a region for which—
a regional forest agreement is in place. What we have here, with the approval of the Democrats, is the minister washing his hands, for 20 years at a national level, of responsibility for the great forests of Western Australia; the wild forests and their wildlife in Victoria and New South Wales; the forests of south-east Queensland; and the forests of world heritage value in such places as the Sticks, Huon, Weld and Picton valleys in Tasmania, the Great Western Tiers, the Tarkine, the North-East and the Tasman Peninsula, just to name some of them.
Democrat approved chainsaws are now moving in on these forests, these ecosystems and this wildlife. When the Democrat approved chainsaws have gone in and felled the forests which the woodchippers want to take—and they are taking 90 per cent of the trees; Senator Murphy might have something to say about what an economic and resource abuse that is—and have sent those trees through the paper mills of Kyoto and Tokyo to the rubbish dumps of the Northern Hemisphere, now approved by the Democrats, the next thing is that the incendiaries will move in.
We have before this Senate at the moment a change in civil aviation regulations to reduce the qualifications required for those pilots who take helicopters or light planes over these ancient forests—once they have been felled and the woodchippers have taken out what they want—and drop thousands of incendiaries to create a firestorm. This is happening at the end of every season in Tasmania. Thousands of hectares of these ancient forests have been felled—rainforests included. Indeed, the Democrat purpose here has become, through those incendiaries, to kill the cotyledons—the little growth opportunities for new rainforest trees—the root systems and any living fur, feather or flower left in this 
 recently ancient ecosystem so that genetically manipulated eucalypts, fast growing for the woodchippers' purposes, will replace them. That is what the Democrats are giving their approval to.
The Democrats have now, through their imprimatur on this legislation, approved the bringing in of 1080 to these wild forests to be sprinkled through the fire holocaust area. Any marsupials—wallabies, potoroos or possums—which hop in from adjacent forests to forage on these genetically manipulated little eucalypt seedlings will be poisoned—murdered by this Democrat action. Senator Bartlett from Queensland, who has been something of an advocate for Animal Liberation but is now a 1080 poisoner, is going to get up here in a minute and tell us that the Democrats have an amendment which they expect the Labor Party and the Greens to join with them in putting through here that will overturn this particular part of the legislation. But it is utter deception, and it is knowing deception, by the Democrats and they will not get away with it.
Let me explain. They went to the table and said to the government, `We want different provisions for the forests. We don't want to be seen as responsible for the 20 years of destruction that Dr Aila Keto has referred to as coming down the line for the forests, with no federal powers to stop it.' This legislation removes all federal powers to stop it. But the government said no. These Democrat puppies, these poodles of Liberal politics, put their tails between their legs and accepted that. But they thought, `We must greenwash. Senator Hill greenwashes all the time and it seems successful. We'll try it. We'll bring in an amendment here which we will get the numbers for if the Independents agree,' knowing that it has no effect. That amendment is not going to go through the House of Representatives, and they know it.
What the Democrats are doing here is giving their stamp of approval to the destruction of the forests for the next 20 years. I cannot accept this pathetic little effort to try to cover up their tracks and deceive their membership, conservationists or anybody else out there—and 87 per cent of people, according to recent West Australian polls, do not 
 want this Democrat destruction of the forests. I cannot accept their little effort to try to deceive people into thinking that they really do care.
Every tree in those forests that dies, every owl's nesting place, every possum, every endangered species—like the great Tasmanian wedgetail, which is bigger than the mainland species, or the white goshawk, which is down to 200 breeding pairs, as I told the Senate two days ago—is now pushed closer to extinction because of Senator Allison, who laughs over there in her seat; because of Senator Bartlett; because of Senator Stott Despoja, who stayed absent from this debate but put her signature on the bottom of this death warrant for forests; because of Senator Lees; because of Senator Murray from Western Australia; and because of Senator Woodley from Queensland. These are the environmental sell-out people.
Senator Bartlett interjecting—
Senator Allison interjecting—
—They are yabbering now—the poodles have been activated. They are down off the Howard lap for a moment while they try to bark at somebody else before they jump into another environmentally destructive lap somewhere further down the line. The trouble with their yabbering is that this is so serious. This is so dreadful for those forests. This is so awesome. And the Democrats have put their stamp of approval on it and have turned their back on the environment which, in the past, they have said they stood for.
—And the Tasmanian Conservation Trust? What a bunch of possums.
—Senator Bartlett intervenes with, `What about a bunch of possums?' I thought he would know better than that. This is a serious matter. But these people do not treat it seriously anymore, because the livelihood of ecosystems and the livelihood of grand forests right round this country was expendable to them to get a place at the table of power.
Senator Bartlett interjecting—
—`Yep,' says Senator Bartlett. He agrees with that analysis because he knows it is true.
—Madam Temporary Chair, I raise a point of order. Senator Brown is obviously willing to misrepresent what is in the legislation, but he is not entitled to misrepresent my statements.
—Senator Bartlett, that is not a point of order. Would you please resume your seat.
—It is inappropriate for him to try to mislead the Senate and put things like that on the record.
—Senator Bartlett, you know that is disorderly. You will have the opportunity to respond at the end of the debate if you believe you have been misrepresented, but it is not a point of order.
—Thank you, Madam Temporary Chairman. You know that reaction underscores the guilt that Senator Bartlett, Senator Allison—still grinning at the back of the chamber—and the absent senators have about this matter. This is environmental perfidy. We all get involved in political cut and thrust but this is a core issue as far as we Greens are concerned. The Democrats have ostensibly been an environmental party and they have used that kudos right down the line. That is now dead. The Democrats are now part of the environmental problem of this country for decades to come. They now have their hands on the chainsaws. They are now in the cockpit of the bulldozers.
—Driven by the Tasmanian Conservation Trust.
—They are trying to blame the Tasmanian Conservation Trust. Let them answer for themselves. They cannot answer for themselves.
—They have already done it.
—This interjecting and, I might add, environmentally despicable senator from Queensland is not going to be able to answer for himself. The people listen 
 ing to this broadcast and the people of Australia can know this: the Democrats will guillotine this debate on forests as well, just the same as they will now chainsaw down forests everywhere that they exist in this country. The Democrats will try to say, `Well, we had one or two individuals in the conservation movement who were looking at specific clauses and lost their view of the wider environmental good,' but they are going to live to regret this day. The problem is that that is now what counts; the problem is that it is the forests of this country that count here.
We have in this legislation at page 41 the death warrant for those forests, and it has now been signed by Senator Lees, Senator Stott Despoja, Senator Murray, Senator Woodley, Senator Bartlett and Senator Vicki Bourne from New South Wales. They have personally signed the death warrant of millions of hectares of Australia's forests in the next 20 years with only this `out': if a federal government should move in those 20 years to do anything to protect those forests, the big woodchip corporations—to whom the Democrats now appeal for funds; they want to be part of the funding from the corporate sector—will be compensated out of the taxpayers' purse. That is what the Democrats have given their seal of approval to in this very anti-environmental measure.

name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—A number of times during that last contribution—if you can call it that—there were frequent comments as to the laughter coming from the Democrats benches. I guess it is a bit hard not to laugh at such a joke, and it is a bit of a shame that someone that did have such credibility on environmental issues in the past has allowed himself to be reduced to that. As I said yesterday, it seems that it can happen occasionally in politics—people have been in it for so long that they forget what they are in it for. I guess that, as Senator Brown has been a politician for around 18 years or so, obviously he now sees his role as a politician as trying to out-compete people like Senator Faulkner and Senator Ray with vitriol, abuse and gross distortions. If that is the way that he wants to perform his role, that is fine. But it is a bit of a shame 
 that someone who does have the opportunity to—and is seen as someone who previously was able to—put forward arguments on behalf of the environment is willing to sacrifice credibility for the sake of what he obviously sees as nothing more than a political opportunity to bash the Democrats.
That, I suppose, demonstrates how much, sadly, he has just simply become a politician that is interested in nothing else but ignoring what he was originally there for—to try and protect the environment—and has simply turned into someone that is willing to seize a political opportunity to attack other political parties that he sees as his opponents. In doing so of course—as highlighted throughout his previous contribution—he is quite willing to misrepresent the facts, distort the facts and completely ignore the facts for the basis of what he sees as his own political campaign. He has obviously chosen to take on that role, and that is a shame, from my point of view, because I would rather see as many credible voices as possible in the parliament promoting and trying to save the environment. It is a bit of an unfortunate situation that he has chosen to ignore that role.
I would make a plea to the conservation groups who work so hard for so little recognition in such a dedicated manner throughout the country to think carefully about this issue. There are clearly differences of opinion amongst conservation groups at the moment. Some of them are still reacting to the significant concerns that the Democrats identified, in conjunction with them during the committee process, with the original bill and have not yet been able to recognise that what the Democrats have achieved here is a major advance for the environment. If they wish to simply take a role of attacking the legislation as a whole and trying to knock off those advances, whether they like to or not they will be associating themselves with the sort of nonsense that Senator Brown is willing to go on with—that, somehow or other, the Democrats are responsible for clear-felling Tasmanian forests.
Of course, for every mention of the word  `Democrats' in his previous contribution—how we have now got our hands on the 
 chainsaw and all of that sort of nonsense—you could go through that speech, cross out `Democrats' and put in `Tasmanian Conservation Trust', who have approved the amendments that the Democrats have managed to gain to this legislation as a significant advance for the environment. So he may as well be criticising the Tasmanian Conservation Trust—and all of those people in the environment movement who have praised this agreement—as equally having their hands on the chainsaws and as equally gleefully staffing the bulldozers.
If he wants to try and divide the environment movement that he as a person has done so much to build up in the past, it is a bit sad. He has now got to a stage where he is willing to use his position as a politician to try and divide and weaken the environment movement that previously he has contributed so much to. That is a shame, but the real problem is in relation to an issue for the environment groups, and I would urge them to consider that. Certainly, as Democrats we have no problem with them calling it as they see it. I know that some of those who have concerns with this amended legislation are doing so. They are going through it and are willing to call it as they see it—as they understand it—as they try to avoid some of the absurd statements that Senator Brown makes. But they do need to be careful that their credibility as environmental advocates is not tarnished if they allow themselves to be associated with such nonsense. It is a shame that for political purposes that sort of risk and that sort of threat is being put to the environment movement.
The issue that we are debating at the moment concerns forests. It is one of the areas where the Democrats, as much as anybody else, have highlighted that there is a failing in this bill. It is an issue on which the Democrats, as much as anybody else, have pledged to continue to fight to protect our forests. But the obvious fact, which has been confirmed by Senator Brown's speech, is that the destruction to the forests is happening now—it is happening now under existing laws—and this parliament is powerless to do anything about it. What we are doing in this legislation 
 in many areas is providing opportunities, for the first time, for the parliament to do something about it. Senator Brown wants to prevent that opportunity and that extra avenue of activity from being able to occur. The Democrats will not ignore the advances that have been achieved in so many areas in protecting the environment through this overall set of amendments simply because we will not be able to ensure that the forests are protected. But we will continue to try and do that. As indicated, we will be moving amendments to put forests back into the bill and to include forests as a trigger.
One of the useful aspects of this debate has been that it has served to rekindle the interests of the Australian Labor Party in the environment. Many Labor Party members who were in the chamber earlier today—not so many are in here now—were suddenly playing the role of being major supporters of the environment. Given that there has been such a lack of any policy position from the Labor Party on the environment since the last election, hopefully this will serve as an opportunity for them to develop a policy on the environment and to put forward indications about what they would do if they were in government. This debate gives them a chance to indicate their policy and to give public statements on how they would protect the environment if they were in government. They have spoken previously about greenhouse. This debate gives them a chance to get their state Labor colleagues in Queensland to come out and say, `We will support greenhouse being put in place as an environment trigger.' The Democrats would welcome them on board because it would give us an opportunity to put that into the legislation, adding to the other gains that have already been made in this area.
As I have said previously, the Democrats do not say that the bill is perfect. As amended, we see it as a significant advance. It is equally important that we highlight the gaps that still exist. The issue of forests is one of those gaps that still exist and where improvements desperately need to be made. Attempts are being made to put around a big fabrication that the inability to address that issue some 
 how leads us to a situation where the forests have even less protection than they have now. That is false. There are any number of indications and explanations that you could give to outline why so many aspects of this legislation are an improvement, but this was probably summarised quite well by Stephen Lunn in today's Australian with the simple headline, `New laws an improvement, but major concerns remain'. That would just about be an assessment of the Democrats' view: this legislation is a significant improvement, but we still have major concerns that we will continue to work on.
The initial comment by Stephen Lunn, leading into his article, was, `The system was broke and needed fixing.' There is still some fixing work to be done, but at least we have a vehicle that will provide us with a better opportunity to make further advances in those areas where there are still significant concerns. This aspect of the legislation that we are debating at the moment deals with the issue of forests. It is an area where the Democrats will be moving amendments to take out the exemption clauses for forests in the bill. I have not seen any amendments put forward by the Labor Party in that regard but, given their new-found concern for the environment, I am sure they will be supporting us in our amendments.
It is equally important, when looking at the whole issue of how we address the legislation and the issue of forests in future, to look at how we can best ensure that mechanisms are in place and that we have a legislative vehicle to make further improvements. This forests section that we are dealing with is a significant problem and it needs to be removed from the bill, because our forests are being destroyed. That is something that is recognised by all conservation groups, including all of those that have supported the amendments and the improvements that the Democrats have managed to achieve.
We have had a lot of involvement through the committee process with conservation groups in the process of developing our amendments. Again, we have heard a lot today about the lack of ability to examine issues because of the need to ensure that these 
 achievements are passed by the parliament before it rises. However, this bill has been subject to a significant number of committee hearings over a long period and the concerns addressed in the amendments that the Democrats have gained support for are based on all of the input from conservation and indigenous groups during the inquiry.
Despite all the noise from Senator Brown, when we look at what he does in his role as a parliamentarian to try to advance the environment, and when we ask how many times he turned up to any of the committee hearings on the environment legislation to hear what the concerns of environment groups were, to ask questions and to try to put the government on the spot about what it was doing, the answer is zero. Senator Brown is quite able to come in here, be the politician and see how he can compete with Senator Faulkner and Senator Ray in the abuse stakes but, when it comes to doing anything other than abusing the Democrats and significant proportions of the environment movement throughout Australia, there is nothing else there; there is nothing else to fall back on.
Let us actually look at what has been achieved by Senator Brown in his role in the Senate on environment issues and at how many amendments he has actually had passed in respect of environment legislation in his time here. Having examined his record on improving things for the environment, I can say that he has had one amendment passed in respect of environment legislation, back in 1997. All seven disallowance motions he has moved have been negatived, the urgency motion has been negatived, and the two references to committees have been negatived. His sole contribution, in terms of a concrete outcome, has been one amendment. Obviously, he makes frequent contributions in terms of hurling abuse at the Democrats, trying to attack the Democrats for political purposes and trying to now split the environment movement to get them onside as an attack weapon against the Democrats for his own political purpose.
I guess we can look at how successful he has been in that regard as well. The other day he was calling on myself and Senator Stott 
 Despoja—as everybody knows, we have indicated our unwillingness to support the tax legislation—and saying, `You disagree with this legislation; you should quit the party if you are serious.' I suppose that shows the obvious consequence of that: if every time you disagreed with other people and your colleagues you split the party, you would end up with a pretty small party pretty quickly. Perhaps that is why Senator Brown is in a party of one, and perhaps why he has achieved only one amendment in his time here.
We are quite willing to work through our differences, and I hope the conservation movement are willing and able to work through their differences constructively. We certainly look forward to working with them in an ongoing fashion constructively in lots of the opportunities that have been gained through passing this legislation as amended. We are quite happy to hear their concerns and to take their criticisms about the areas that still need work, and we will do that constructively. If we have concerns or disagreements about their assessments, we will discuss that with them. That is the measure of the Democrats' work and the approach we are going to take, and we are going to keep doing that because we are here to get gains for the environment.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—I wish to make a few comments in respect of both what Senator Bartlett has said and this part of the proceedings. It is quite understandable that Senator Bartlett would take the position he has taken. It is basically a very pathetic response to the arguments put forward by the opposition and the Greens this morning. But Senator Bartlett is basically, I think, working on the basis of ignorance. He comes in here and tries to pull on this stunt and in doing so tries to argue that the Democrats still have a compelling conviction and commitment to environmental issues. As part of that, he says that they have achieved improvements.
Senator Bartlett, you can quote any journalist you want, but you have had direct advice this morning from Associate Professor Robert Fowler, Director of the Australian Centre for 
 Environmental Law, and he has put it to you that your deal does not deliver; your deal does not enhance protection. In fact, he put this to you:
I reluctantly conclude that the amended bill is still inferior to the existing scheme of adhockery triggers for Commonwealth assessment and approval in relation to environmental matters.
He has asked you to reconsider this particular aspect of the bill. This is a person who has been a guru to the green movement and to the Democrats. This is a person whom Senator Allison praised lavishly in hearings, and he has put direct to you that you have failed and that the pretence you are putting to the Senate and to the Australian public is a fraud. You do not understand constitutional law, Senator Bartlett. If you did understand constitutional law, you would have acknowledged that over 20 years from 1970—30 years—because of the environment movement, because of Labor in government, because of activities of people like Senator Brown and Senator Margetts, we have actually enhanced the scope for Commonwealth interest, activity and legislative capacity.
Those cases that were fought through Tasmania and through Queensland have given the Commonwealth an enhanced role and capacity to act in respect of the environment. It is that law that you are now unwinding. It is that law that you are winding back. You have failed, Senator Bartlett, and you cannot run away from that. Unfortunately for the environment, for the whole morning the record will show that, while the debate has raged on in this place, the Democrats have sat there like dummies in a sideshow, like those clowns that you see with heads moving, nothing coming out of them—absolutely nothing of any relevance. That has been your role now and that, I must say, has been your role in terms of negotiating outcomes.
You come here now and say, `Well, we would have considered a greenhouse trigger.' You had the chance to vote for one. You sat there compliantly while Senator Hill refused us leave to move it. There was a greenhouse trigger moved this morning. I sought leave to move it separately to the rest. Where was your voice, Senator Bartlett? Where was 
 Senator Allison? Where was Senator Lees? Nowhere to be heard. Now, having sold out on the constitutional basis for Commonwealth action, having sold out on greenhouse triggers, what do you do? You come in here and move a stunt.
Why wasn't this issue—if you are so committed to it—a core issue in your discussions with Senator Hill? Why do you raise it now as an afterthought? You know full well that the only way you could have organised delivery on this, that you could have delivered anything on this, was to have put it on the table with the government. The numbers in this place are not sufficient to deliver.
—They wimped.
—Of course they wimped. They were not brave enough. I pay tribute to Senator Hill. He has conned them. He has conned them superbly. They might have lost, but the environment is the loser as well. Senator Hill can walk away with his legislation. He has set up a couple of committees and a couple of processes—he is happy. That is all he has had to give, a bit of embroidery. But you have been conned and you have sold out on everything that you have believed in.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, would you please address your remarks through the chair.
Senator Hill interjecting—
—I am not suggesting that at all. I am suggesting they were conned. So you come in here and raise this as an afterthought. As I say, if it is a fundamental issue, you should have organised an outcome with the government. Why not recognise that the numbers are not in this place sufficient to force this on the government? Now you try and cover up your sell-out. That is all this is about: `let us try a bit of fluff in the air and let us see if we can divert people's attention and let us see if, through that, we can put the heat on Senator Brown and on the Labor Party and so on.'
But just think of what you are doing. Firstly, you are imposing a guillotine on this debate. Secondly, you know that the only way 
 it could have got up was through the government. But by imposing the guillotine on this bill, do you know what you are doing? You are ensuring that there is time for the RFA legislation to be debated in this place and to go through. That is the direct result of your complicity in the most undemocratic manoeuvre taken in this place for the 18 years that I have been here. You will ensure, through your complicity in the guillotine, that we will get RFA legislation. It does not matter what you do; it does not matter what we or the Democrats do.
We have got amendments, and the amendments that we will move to the RFA legislation represent an advance on what you have agreed to in this legislation. You have signed up to this bill—all seven of you. You have signed up to a regime that we are still trying to improve and which we will move amendments to improve, in terms of linking it to national forest policy, in terms of tighter definitions and in terms of accountability in this place. Where were those amendments in your discussions with the government? They were nowhere to be seen.
So do not come in here now, at the end of this debate, having sold out, having signed up, having not got anything out of the process with Senator Hill on the forests, and say to the world, `We're greener than the Greens and we're better than the Labor Party.' You were probably a kid when the Labor Party was pursuing constitutional cases in the High Court to expand Commonwealth power. When Senator Hill, amongst others, was out there belting the cause for states rights, promoting and protecting Joh Bjelke-Petersen whenever he wanted to use a bulldozer to go through anything, we had those debates in here. We had those attacks on the then Attorney-General, Senator Evans. We actually fought the hard fight. We do know about environmental issues, Senator Bartlett, but we also know about the complexity of them. We are not conned like kids in a creche in respect of this, as you have been.
You should lift your standard. In lifting your standard, could I give you a bit of advice: it does you no service to go out there and say of the peak environmental movement, 
 `We can't trust them,' as your leader said this morning. They cannot trust you, and with good cause. You reinforce that distrust by coming in here after the event, facilitating debate, facilitating the bringing on of the RFA legislation, having achieved absolutely nothing. We will try to enhance the government's position, but we will do that in the RFA legislation. We will not fall for your stunt here.

name: Margetts, Sen Dee
text:
—The issue that we are dealing with here is in relation to forests. The reason that we are dealing with it is because it is one of the triggers that do not exist under this new legislation. The quite clear information that was provided in the report that was signed by the Greens and the Democrats in relation to this bill indicated that the original bill was abysmal in terms of how it was to be a vehicle to wind back the Commonwealth's responsibilities. That was clear, and there was a solid bank of opinion.
The government and Democrat amendments barely change this abysmal situation. The only changes are those at the margin in terms of ensuring adequate and effective Commonwealth roles. They are marginal. It is in fact mere tinkering. I heard Senator Hill yesterday, in a comment by way of an aside, explaining about the number of amendments. He said, `Most of these are merely technical.' Basically, the minister, if I overheard him correctly, does not consider these amendments to be particularly significant. That is why he said it is okay to have them in large chunks. So the minister did not think they were particularly significant.
The bill remains a major step backwards. There is no way of getting around this. There may be some groups who think that, for a particular issue, they might get better coverage than they have got now. But the overall picture involves a massive step backwards. To borrow the words of Senator Stott Despoja regarding the Reith-Kernot agreement in relation to industrial relations, it is draconian legislation only marginally improved. That goes for this legislation as well. Quantity should not be confused with quality. There may be 400 or so amendments that the Demo 
 crats have achieved, but in terms of overall substance, they are inadequate. Maybe 20 per cent of those are what is needed for good environmental legislation and have been achieved, not the 80 per cent that has been claimed. The numbers do not actually relate to the quality of the concerns that people have.
Make no mistake: the government still have a number of triggers—that is, a mere six—and it will not be hard to give them exemptions for every one of these. When we are talking about endangered species, if the issue focuses on the clearance of their habitat, the government will weasel out of it if they can.
There is an urgent need, as many people have said, for a greenhouse trigger. Where are the commitments by the government to do other than consult with the states? I have not seen a single promise from the government about doing anything other than consult. With respect to land clearance and water, what do the Democrats claim? Merely that land clearing may be regulated if it affects a matter of national environmental significance. I cannot find a single amendment that relates to land clearing, water or the stating of the obvious situation—that something may be regulated if it affects the NES matter about which they are claiming to have achieved a partial result, even if the probability of significant land clearance being stopped is minuscule.
As for the forests, which is what this bunch of amendments is about, the Democrats have not achieved anything. They have not even consulted with the Greens on the matter, despite knowing how concerned we are about the exemption of forests from the bill. This lack of consultation is now par for the course. Just consulting with a few select groups, when it should have been possible to consult all in the process, illustrates the tactics that the Democrats have learnt from the government—that is, pick off the groups that you think may be easily scared. If we are talking about threats, the major threat, as has been mentioned, comes out in this Democrat release, which says:
It was clear to the Democrats that the ALP-Greens strategy was an extremely risky one. If Senators Harradine and Colston supported the bill, the 
 Democrats would have had to start to argue for the very substantial amendments required on the floor of the chamber.
Shock, horror! The release continues:
Clearly, this would have exposed the environment to unacceptable risk. There was much to lose and the potential for real gains was ignored.
The government said their priority in this section of the parliamentary program was the tax package. The government said that again and again and again. For public credibility, the agreement should have been that, if the government's priority was the tax package, the time priority should also have been for the tax package.
We are not in a situation where this Senate has been debating the committee stage of this bill for days on end, even though it is important enough to have done so and the number of amendments and the complexity would warrant that happening. We are not in that situation. The gag was imposed before we even started on the committee stage of an environment bill. So, here we are dealing with, in my understanding, an unprecedented situation where a minor party in this case is using a gag in a situation where they themselves have argued in the opposite direction in the past. Where is the logic? I have thought and thought to see where that logic is. The only answer I can get is about as unkind as I can be at this stage, which is that in the recent past there has been a situation where the Democrats wanted to regain a seat in Western Australia. Of course, they have won that—to my loss, to the green network's loss and, I believe, now obviously to the wider network's loss because we know what they will do with that power. They have already signed up to it. With that loss of competition, temporarily, from Western Australia—hey, there is no need to be put down as the true green party and no need to appeal to that electorate because they think they have got it sewn up.
I do not usually make statements like this but this is all I can think of that must have been in the minds of the Australian Democrats in reaching this decision. We saw yesterday quite clearly that they did not have to be pushed at this time. We saw they had a 
 golden opportunity to say, `Let's listen to what Aboriginal groups, peak conservation groups and the wider community are saying and let's leave this committee stage until the August sittings. Let's make sure that the new bill'—which it is—`is then given a chance for consultation.' No, not good enough. The opportunity was here. It was not taken. So, it was a nonsense to suggest—and I believe it was an unfair threat to the environment movement in Australia to do so—that they had to make a decision then because otherwise something worse would happen. Unfortunately, the worse thing that is going to happen is that after the end of June we are not even going to have a say. I am certainly not going to have a say on these issues. There won't even be this concern by the Democrats that there might be someone else around from Western Australia at least to show where they are wrong in their statements and where they are not representing their electorates, which they promised to do. All of the statements, all of those leaflets, about protection of the forest are now clearly shown to be false because they have let down that community, let down that electorate, unnecessarily.
The Democrats assert that the disallowable nature of the management plans will ensure stringency. I can only foreshadow that exactly the same thing could happen with any disastrous plans of management as is happening with this bill. We do not know now that the Democrats will not be thrown some crumbs in order to pass it because, when nobody that I know of can understand why this decision is being made now and rushed on and pushed on without debate and gagged, I cannot guarantee—and I do not think anyone can guarantee—what would happen if those disallowances come to the Senate. Since the plans of management can only be disallowed and not amended, those crumbs will be in some totally different area and the Australian people will be left with bilateral agreements that give the Commonwealth power.
Note that the Democrats and government did not support the Greens' amendment to retain even a Commonwealth reserve power so that the Commonwealth can intervene in, say, a development project if state processes 
 are totally inadequate. Madam Chair, as I say, the reasons behind this deal originally escaped me, but I do recall that Senator Lees went through a `pick me, pick me' stage in relation to the consultation and sell-out in relation to tax. The only thing that I can suggest is that after the `pick me, pick me' it became very hard to move away from the table. There are also people, I admit, from the environment movement who were attracted to that feeling of power at the table. It is very difficult for people in that situation not to see how badly they are being done over—and unfortunately they were.
The environment movement, yes, has been divided in this process. It has not been the Greens dividing that movement. The movement was very clear and has put in hours of work. And I know because I have seen people in my office from environmental defenders and we have put in many hours. I have had a volunteer worker working with me day in, day out for months on this issue. You cannot talk to me about the work that has been done, because I know that that work has now been betrayed for the sake of the Democrats and some people from the environment movement who thought it would be good to be at the table, despite the fact there was no need for them to be forced to be there.
If Senator Harradine or Senator Colston had considered that they wanted to pass this bill, the indications were not here yesterday. But even if they had, if I were in that situation I would not want my name on that bill. The government are laughing all the way to the bank. They cannot believe that the Democrats have put themselves in this situation of taking the heat for what in fact is the government's abysmal bill; and that is what has happened. The government cannot believe their luck. If this deal had been made, carried on and debated after the 30 June, there would be no clearer indication that it was a Democrat deal. At the moment the Democrats can pretend that they had to do it because something worse might happen if they had not. After 30 June there would have been no excuse and that is the reason why we are being forced to vote on this now; that is the reason why our 
 forests will get no further protection and that is the reason why we are being restricted to six matters in a very narrow way that is worse than what exists now.
The minister and other ministers in this government have clearly said they do not want people asking about wider issues if there was an export power involved. They do not want people, for legitimate reasons, questioning very bad decisions by state governments. The federal government do not want to deal with it and this is what has been achieved in this bill. It is no wonder it is being rushed through now. It is no wonder that the amendments by non-government parties have not even been allowed to be put. I have been here six years and I have never seen that situation in the Senate before. Okay, lots of things happen in the House of Representatives, but this is supposed to be the states' house. This is supposed to be the people's house. I have never seen a situation like this where cross benchers, in a party that is supposed to be about the environment, have denied the right of minor parties to put their amendments.
Was this part of the original agreement and, if it was not, I believe the Democrats would have had the right to say to the government, `All bets are off unless you give other people the chance to put their amendments. This is not part of our agreement and all bets are off.' There is still the opportunity for the Democrats to say that all bets are off unless we have a proper debate; that all bets are off unless we have the chance to scrutinise these bills in a democratic way so that people can see what we have agreed to.
But no, I have not seen this. Even if we voted on them all at the end of the time, all in a lump, how meaningless that process has become. I believe that the people from my own state of Western Australia will be feeling very betrayed as a result of what has gone on in the last couple of days. Some people thought there would be some deals associated, but I do not think very many people realised how bad this would be in relation to the forests, which is what these amendments are. In my state I know that people have very, very long memories.

name: Hill, Sen Robert
text:
—I just wanted to respond in relation to the forests and point out that the Greens have had so many opportunities in this place to make a difference on matters of forest protection and have taken up none of them. What I find so extraordinary is that, when the government brings forward environmental reform legislation which is designed to achieve better national environmental outcomes, it gets damned by the Greens without any willingness to contribute to developing a process to achieve a better outcome.
We offered the Greens, as we offered the Australian Labor Party, the opportunity to work with us towards better environmental outcomes. I know that as a matter of principle Senator Bob Brown will not work with the government, no matter what the consequence. No matter what benefit he could get for the environment, he still will not work with the government to achieve that benefit. I do not understand it. I presume it is just something to do with his past when he made his name as a confrontationist and became a hero to the green movement as it then was. He is concerned that by now moving on and being prepared to negotiate better environmental outcomes would in some way put him at risk with his very small remaining constituency. I can only assume that that is what this is all about. I regret that. When we look back at the opportunities that Senator Brown has had over the past few years to achieve better environmental outcomes in this place we see that he has wasted the whole lot. I just cannot understand why the remainder of his green constituency stands by him.
When I look at the advantages—and I see nothing wrong with this at all—that Senator Harradine, for example, has been able to achieve for Tasmania, I would have thought that Senator Brown, also being a Tasmanian senator and one who claims to be here representing an environment constituency, would have recognised that he had the opportunity to win some real gains for the environment. But has he ever come to our door and said, `I want a better green outcome and this is my proposition'? Of course not. When we come 
 to him and say, `Do you want to participate in a process to achieve a better green outcome?', he washes his hands of us. In other words, to preserve his political stature with what remains of his constituency, he sacrifices the opportunity to achieve a better environmental outcome.
I know that is Senator Brown and there is nothing much we can do about it, but I would have thought Senator Margetts, who I know has a genuine interest in the forests of Western Australia, would have approached this matter differently. I would have thought she would say, `If the government is going to embark upon a major environmental reform, this is a wonderful opportunity for the green parties to become involved in the process to seek to achieve some of our aspirations.' Is that not logical? Is there some major flaw in my logic? But of course they will not do so. In other words, she has been wedded to the Bob Brown style of politics which is not to work with governments to achieve better outcomes but to go out there and run the old battles of the past and to try to achieve what? Notoriety, personal notoriety. That is the aspiration of Senator Bob Brown and it is very much a regret to me that Senator Margetts is prepared to lock herself into the same political mentality and sacrifice the opportunities that she has had to achieve better green outcomes.
How could negotiating with the government to achieve a better green outcome be described as selling out her principle? How does Senator Margetts know if she has never tried, if she refuses to participate in a process? How can she assume that the outcome would not have achieved any of her goals? That is the fundamental flaw in the position of both the green members of this Senate, and I think it is very much a matter of regret, not for me of course but for the environment, because there are people out there that have elected Senator Brown and Senator Margetts because they actually thought that they would make a difference. But as has been demonstrated today, they have not made a difference at all. They have wasted their time in this place. They certainly have looked for political notoriety, particularly in the case of Senator 
 Brown, but they have achieved no outcomes for their constituency.
They can stand up and say `We've fought the good fight, we belt the government every day', but that does not get a better environmental outcome. Why don't they join with the 4,000-odd Landcare groups and conservation groups and get out there into the forest and do something worth while for the forests.
Senator Margetts interjecting—
—Pull a few weeds, Senator Margetts. Get into a bit of revegetation. (Time expired)
—The question is that amendment No. 73 moved by the government be agreed to. 
Question resolved in the affirmative.
—I now automatically put amendment No. 74. The question is that the following amendment be agreed to:
Clause 41, page 43 (line 19), omit "(3)", substitute "(1)".
Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Bartlett, Sen Andrew
text:
—Madam Temporary Chairman, I seek leave to move Democrat amendments 1 to 3 and 6 to 10.
—Madam Temporary Chair, when I tried to move amendments after the expiry of time I was told I could not do so. I presume that same ruling applies now.
Senator Hill interjecting—
—I was told I could not seek leave after 1.30 p.m.
—Senator Bolkus, I am advised that that is not the case; that because Senator Bartlett sought leave after 1.30 p.m., he is entitled to seek leave. Is leave granted?
Leave granted.
—On a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman: I want to have it recorded that I will be granting leave, despite the fact that this morning the Democrats have been complicit in blocking every 
 Green and Labor amendment from getting the similar privilege of a vote.
—There is no point of order, Senator Brown.
—On a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman: I want it recorded that once again Senator Brown has misled the Senate by implying that the Democrats blocked amendments previously.
—Senator Bartlett, we must move on with the debate.
—I move:
(1)	 Clause 11, page 8 (lines 20 and 21), omit "taken in accordance with Regional Forest Agreements or".
(2)	 Page 25 (after line 20), after Subdivision F, insert:
Subdivision FA—Forestry operations
24A  Requirement for approval of forestry operations
	 (1)	 A constitutional corporation, the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth agency must not undertake forestry operations that have, will have or are likely to have a significant impact on the environment.
		 Civil penalty:
		 (a)	 for an individual—5,000 penalty units;
		 (b)	 for a body corporate—50,000 penalty units.
	 (2)	 A person must not, for the purposes of trade or commerce:
		 (a)	 between Australia and another country; or
		 (b)	 between 2 States; or
		 (c)	 between a State and a Territory; or
		 (d)	 between 2 Territories;
		 undertake forestry operations that have, will have or are likely to have a significant impact on the environment.
		 Civil penalty:
		 (a)	 for an individual—5,000 penalty units;
		 (b)	 for a body corporate—50,000 penalty units.
	 (3)	 A person must not undertake in a Territory forestry operations that have, will have or are likely to have a significant impact on the environment.
		 Civil penalty:
		 (a)	 for an individual—5,000 penalty units; 

		 (b)	 for a body corporate—50,000 penalty units.
	 (4)	 Subsections (1), (2) and (3) do not apply to an action that is a forestry operation if:
		 (a)	 an approval of the taking of the action by the constitutional corporation, Commonwealth agency, Commonwealth or person is in operation under Part 9 for the purposes of this section; or
		 (b)	 Part 4 lets the constitutional corporation, Commonwealth agency, Commonwealth or person take the action without an approval under Part 9 for the purposes of this section; or
		 (c)	 there is in force a decision of the Minister under Division 2 of Part 7 that:
			 (i)	 the action is not a controlled action; or
			 (ii)	 the action is a controlled action but this section is not a controlling provision for the action; or

		 (d)	 the action is an action described in subsection 160(2) (which describes actions whose authorisation is subject to a special environmental assessment process), or the giving of an authorisation (however described) of such an action. 
24B  What are  forestry operations ?
	 In this Act:
 forest products  means live or dead trees, ferns or shrubs, or parts thereof.
 forestry operations  means any of the following done for commercial purposes:
		 (a)	 the planting of trees;
		 (b)	 the managing of trees before they are harvested;
		 (c)	 the harvesting of forest products;
	 and includes any related land clearing, land preparation and regeneration (including burning) and transport operations.
(3)	 Clause 34, page 36 (after table item 13), insert:

		 (aa)	 for the purposes of section 24A of forestry operations:
			 (i)	 by a person for the purposes of trade or commerce between Australia and another country or between 2 States; or

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN —The question is that the amendments moved by Senator Bartlett be agreed to.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—Madam Chair, I seek leave to move Greens (WA)-Australian Greens amendment No. 21 on sheet 1443, which returns to the minister the power to intervene to protect forest environments.
—The question will be divided on that particular clause. Is there any objection?
Leave granted.
—Again I seek clarification. On the running sheet it seems that both the Australian Democrats and the Greens have put down the same amendments.
—It is not an amendment. It is a request for it to be divided so that it can be voted on.
—It is to oppose clauses 38 to 42.
—Yes.
—On my running sheet, the Australian Democrats have been listed before the Greens.
—It makes no difference; it was whoever took the call first. Senator Bartlett ceded to Senator Brown. Is leave granted for clauses 38 to 42 to be divided?
Leave granted.
—The question is that clauses 38 to 42 stand as printed.

name: Hill, Sen Robert
text:
—I seek leave to take amendments Nos 175 to 445 together, as on sheet DT218.
Leave not granted.
—I move government amendment No. 175:
(175) 	 Clause 176, page 160 (line 5), at the end of subclause (1), add "In preparing the plan, the Minister must carry out public consultation on a draft of the plan in accordance with the regulations.".
I wanted to make a few comments on this chapter of the bill because it is the first conservation of biodiversity law at a federal level in Australia's history. We have had a situation where Australia is a party to the International Convention on the Protection of Biodiversity, and some years ago there was in fact a strategy for the conservation of biodiversity negotiated between the Commonwealth and the states. Regrettably, the last Labor government did not take the one extra step and set up a legal framework at the Commonwealth level to implement its commitments under that strategy. We are very pleased that the Howard government has been prepared to take the initiative and provide for Australia its first law for the conservation of biodiversity.
The amendments to the chapter improve the provisions for management of species and ecological communities and of protected areas, and also they continue the statutory office of the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service, which I will come back to in a minute. The amendments provide for increased recognition of the important role of indigenous peoples in conserving biodiversity and managing jointly managed Commonwealth reserves. In particular, representatives of the traditional owners will have the power to withhold consent, within reason, to the appointment to the joint management board of a person nominated by the Northern Territory. The amendments provide increased transparency for listing species and ecological communities and for decisions about permits relating to them. Strict liability is applied to some offences or elements of offences. It will now be possible to list key threatening processes purely on the basis of scientific criteria. Whilst I mention key threatening processes, it also overcomes the technical deficiency in the previous legislation which meant that a process could not be listed if it crossed the boundary between state and Commonwealth jurisdictions. So some of those matters 
 that were not listed on a technical basis could be reconsidered in the future.
I would also take the opportunity to thank the volunteers, really, within the scientific community who have given us advice, and so much sound advice, in endangered species areas. In fact, the men and women on the advisory bodies that we have in this area—the biodiversity advisory body, our threatened species scientific body and threatened species advisory body—do play a very important part in the conservation of our biodiversity through the assistance that they give to government and in the community leadership that they provide. It is not sufficiently or often enough recognised, and I am pleased to do so today. Also, the capacity to proclaim conservation zones to afford interim protection to the areas while their values are assessed will be retained.
I said I wanted to come back to the matter of the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. Although there has been much comment about the number of amendments before the chamber, in fact many of those amendments simply relate to reinstatement of that position. It is no secret that we in the government believe that there was opportunity within this legislation to streamline administrative structures in relation to environmental protection and as such to remove what some would say is simply another tier in the structure—that is, the position of the director as a statutory officer—and then have a more clearly defined line of command and responsibility between government and the decision making process in relation to national parks.
That policy preference was consistent with the stand this government has taken across portfolios—that where possible separate statutory authorities should be removed. Regrettably, in the past so many have been created really as a cushion for government, and in particular for ministers, to avoid having to take direct responsibility. That is not the view of this government. This government believes that ministers should take responsibility for decisions that are made and not pass that responsibility off to third parties in the form of statutory authorities. Having 
 said that, and still believing that it would be sound administrative restructuring, it was strongly objected to by the joint boards, to which we are a party, for, in particular, Kakadu National Park and Uluru.
After sitting down with the traditional owners on a number of occasions—it is interesting, because I have heard in this debate those on the other side asserting that there was no consultation on this issue with indigenous people—I have not been able to convince them that the removal of the position would not be seen as some symbolic downgrading of the relationship. Of course, it was the director who signed the leases. Out of respect to the traditional owners, I therefore took the decision to not proceed with that proposed reform. Of course, to reinstate the position of director has meant that many clauses have had to be re-amended, and that makes up a large block of the amendments that are before us today. That is why we revised our opinion on this matter. It does in fact demonstrate that consultation does work and that this government is prepared to listen. Where a decision is going to cause distress, even though we might think it is sound administrative practice, we will vote to avoid distress.
In relation to the Northern Territory representative, we are not moving from our strong commitment that the administration of both parks would be enhanced by a Northern Territory representative. But I would like to stress, contrary to what was asserted in the Senate yesterday, that we are talking about one person, one representative, on boards that have a majority of traditional owners. Furthermore, what we are providing through these amendments is that the nominated representative must be approved by the traditional owners—in other words, it will be with the consent of the traditional owners. We have provided that that consent will not be unreasonably withheld, because unfortunately in my experience third parties, including the ALP, put considerable pressure upon traditional owners in these matters. I listened to the ALP's presentation yesterday in relation to the Northern Territory, and it was a totally unjustified and unreasonable condemnation of the 
 Northern Territory government. I have to say that, based on my dealings with the new Chief Minister in the Northern Territory, he is somebody who wants to build a good working relationship with indigenous Territorians, as they were called in the debate yesterday. I say that that is something that should be recognised and applauded.
Progress reported.

name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
text:
—Madam President, yesterday I gave an answer to a question and I promised Senator Woodley that if there was more I could add I would. Yesterday in question time Senator Woodley asked me a number of questions about the Albury-Wodonga Freeway. The answers are in the same order as the questions were asked yesterday. In relation to question (1), the costs of the project are being refined, including the impact of final project design. The final project designs are to be put on public display and there may be some further refinement of the costs as a result of the consultation process.
In relation to question (2), the answer is yes. The economic analysis carried out during the EIS process took account of the social and health costs and impacts. In relation to question (3), in conjunction with the refining of costs of the internal route, a review of the external route costings is being undertaken. The results of this review are being finalised now and the New South Wales government is to provide the Commonwealth with a report on this.
In relation to questions (4) and (5), Senator Woodley, I think I dealt with them yesterday. However, I can add that, while you were suggesting that the majority of your Albury residents are opposed to the internal route, with respect there is also very strong evidence to support the opposite claim. I note two articles in the Border Mail dated 18 and 19 June in which a couple of independent community groups and the state member for Benambra, Mr Tony Plowman MLA, whom I omitted yesterday in my list of the elected representatives who support the internal route, are indicated as strongly supporting the internal route.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—I want to speak about indigenous issues because during the course of the day we have not as yet had a chance to address what is another important area of debate and concern in the community in respect of this legislation. One group of people who have been misled and done over by the final compromise between the Democrats and the Greens are indigenous Australians. This is an environment bill and a lot of people would be misled into thinking that maybe there are not enormous indigenous issues in respect of this legislation. The truth of the matter is that there are. Whether it is in respect of diversity, hunting and gathering rights, native title rights or the management of some pretty important national parks in Australia, indigenous Australians have a role by law and by social policy. 
Probably the most fundamental role is that if we as a parliament were to take more than token recognition of the concept of self-determination, we should involve indigenous Australians in decision making, particularly as it affects them directly, as is does in this legislation. In the last few hours there have been a number of press statements issued by indigenous organisations, including the Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park Board of Management, the Kakadu Board of Management and the Central Land Council. The issue of self-determination is best summed up by the media release from the Central Land Council, where Tracker Tilmouth not only condemns the deal but makes the point that:
The debate has been deliberately limited and has excluded many Aboriginal people who are still not fully across the issues.
He goes on to say:
Until there is a political process which is inclusive of Indigenous interests the question of our very basic right to self determination remains a myth.
He calls his press statement, `Political process sends us back to the mission'. Later on, I will go to the press release from the Kakadu Board of Management, but it is also worth noting at the outset one of the comments that Mick Alderson, the Chairperson of the Kakadu Board of Management, makes in respect of the way they have been treated. He speaks on behalf of not only Aboriginal members but also the tourism representative of the Kakadu Board of Management. They express their concern and he says:
We are tired of being treated like jacky-jackys, sitting on the sideline watching non-Aboriginal people making decisions about our land.
These people raise these sorts of concerns because they have been misled, not just by the government but also by the Australian Democrats. It was this minister who wrote to the boards of management saying that there would not be a change in the management arrangements without the consent of the boards. The next thing they knew was that legislation had been introduced to change the structure of the boards of management. There was no consultation in between and no consent sought. The minister just comes in here and introduces legislation, and not only does he not consult but he breaks a commitment 
 and a promise. Further down the track, this felony is compounded by the Australian Democrats, who not only sell them out but try to portray their sell out as a great win for indigenous Australians. That is adding insult to injury, Senator Allison.
When you look at yesterday's press statement from the Australian Democrats, you see that they claim to have acted in the interests of indigenous Australians; they claim to have acted to stop the appointment of Northern Territory government representatives on the boards of the two Territory national parks—Ulura-Kata Tjuta and Kakadu. Big achievement! But if you read on in the documentation, you find that that achievement is not what it appears to be. Basically, they chose a deliberate course of deception and deceit, not just of indigenous Australians but of the broader Australian public. This is the mob who claimed victory on the environment legislation when the most eminent constitutional lawyers in the country told them that they had failed.	So we should not be surprised about what they have done.
They have told indigenous Australians, `Look, we have taken measures to ensure that there will not be a Territory rep on the board of management,' but when you go into the documentation, that is further redefined to mean that the appointment of a Northern Territory rep on the boards of Kakadu and Uluru-Kata Tjuta national parks is now subject to the consent of traditional owners, with the rider `which may not be withheld unreasonably'. If you go further into the documentation to try to work out what that means, you find that if they resist—if the boards of management do not like a Northern Territory rep on the board of management—the decision will be taken out of their hands and given to the Commonwealth Ombudsman.
This is defence protection Australian Democrats style. This is the new wave of Australian Democrats social conscious and social policy: `Sell them out and try to make them feel good on the way through.' Senator Allison, this is the depths of deceit and you ought to be ashamed of yourself in respect of it. I have been with you when you have looked traditional owners, the elders of these communi 
 ties, straight in the face and said, `I will not let you down.' Not only have you let them down but you have tried to con them on the way through. Your voice is worthless in that community from now on and that is depicted by the press statements, releases and letters from these boards of management.
They write to Senator Meg Lees of their concerns about the proposed bill. They call on the Democrats to stall the debate. They want to have time to look at the amendments. These are not unreasonable things, given the fact that the sorts of people we are talking about and the sorts of management structures we are talking about are very successful examples of management by indigenous Australians. Kakadu was the first place in Australia to set up a joint management model. It has been internationally recognised and other parks, not just in Australia but around the world, have learned from us and have made stronger laws for joint management. That is the view of the Chair of the Kakadu Board of Management, Mick Alderson.
But what do we do here? We have put poison in the well. We have put a Northern Territory government representative on the board of Kakadu, and of Uluru. Maybe not on day 1, but give it three months and it happens. Three months is not a long time to wait for the Northern Territory government; they have waited a long time. They are on record in their most recent statements on this matter as saying that they want to take over control of these national parks. These are things that you cannot avoid, that you cannot run away from, Senator Allison, because they were told to you directly. You were there in Darwin at the meetings, and I was sitting next to you, when the Northern Territory government representatives made it very clear that they wanted to take over. They still want to take over. There is distrust there.
You have a great board of management structure that is working. So what do you do? You bow to the government again. Why? People have to ask themselves why you are doing this. These are the most fundamental rights. You know they are fundamental rights because, not only are they social rights, rights of decency and rights of recognition enshrined 
 in international covenants, they are also rights enshrined in leases under our law.
Those leases provide—and you yourself know full well they provide because, once again, we have had copies presented to us—that in circumstances such as this, even if legislation is introduced to disrupt or overturn the established management structures of those boards, whether it is Kakadu, Uluru or Wreck Bay, the traditional owners have a right to revoke those leases. It is a legal right of theirs. But, in total disregard for this—and we expect it from the government because the minister made his position clear from the start—you have traded away these legal and social rights in secret, without consultation, pretending to represent all these people.
—Outrageous!
—It is outrageous, Senator Crossin. No wonder these people reckon that they are seen by the political process of Australia as `Jacky Jackys, sitting on the sideline'. As I said, there are major concerns. They have been spelt out in the two letters to Senator Lees and the press statement. The concerns as stated in the Central Land Council media release are that:
The Bill
.	 severely restricts traditional and subsistence use of wildlife by limiting use for traditional purposes as laid out in the Native Title Act 1994 and removes existing protection in the National Parks and Wildlife Act 1974
We do not know to what extent this government is going to reinstate the role of the National Parks and Wildlife Director. But we do know that the independence of that position has been marginalised enormously over the last 12 to 18 months. I sat next to Senator Allison, hand-wringing and expressing concern about what had been happening, about how a public servant under the direction of the minister was now in that position. That concern does not filter through in terms of any outcome of the compromise in the agreement between the Democrats and the government. The next point in the press release expresses concern that the bill:
.	 ignores native title and cultural heritage protection laws 

Your protection of existing native title rights, as agreed with the government, is not good enough; it is not adequate enough. You cannot hide behind incompetence on that one because you knew, and you continue to know, that that was an issue. But did you seek consultation with those who have actually defended Aboriginal Australians in respect of native title? Did you become aware of it? Did you let them come to the table as you were sitting there, cozy with the Prime Minister, Senator Hill and others from the government? There was no room for black people at the table of negotiation on this particular bill when it came to even their most fundamental rights. The deal does not protect the Native Title Act, which passed this place after a long debate less than a year ago. How do you reconcile that? How will you go back to your supporters in Victoria and explain to them that you have actually sold out on the protection of that Native Title Act? You are going to have to. The press release further states that the bill:
.	 does not provide an effective framework for negotiation of indigenous land use agreements . . . 
That is another area in contradiction to the Native Title Act 1993. The next point states that the bill:
.	 allows the Commonwealth to transfer responsibility to the States and Territories without sufficient accountability
To some extent, you have protected against bilaterals, but you have not protected against that list of myriad mechanisms that are available under legislation for this minister, this government, to basically flick-off responsibilities in that area. The second last point is that:
.	 there is no requirement for consultation with indigenous stakeholders
You would not want that, because you have not had it. You have not allowed them at the table, so it is no wonder that that does not find itself in the legislation. The last point states that this bill:
.	 gives the Commonwealth Minister wide discretion in key areas
That is right; that is something that your minority report expressed concern about. So we do have here a sell-out of the Kakadu, 
 Uluru—Kata Tjuta and Wreck Bay national parks and the destruction of their boards of management. But I suppose the most offensive thing about all this is that it has been done with absolutely no participation of indigenous Australians. Their view, as last expressed to us, is that they want more time. They do not want the Northern Territory rep. They reckon—not only do they reckon but the international bodies reckon—that they have a good board of management structure. You have sold out on that; you have done it in the dark and you have done it trying to mislead the people most directly affected.
So I say to you: any time you put your head up, Senator Allison, and any time the Democrats put their heads up in the future pretending to be defenders of indigenous Australians, we will remind you of two things—the fact that you have sold out their rights and the fact that you have sold them out without even warning them and trying to deceive them.

name: Allison, Sen Lyn
text:
—Since Senator Bolkus quotes so freely from press releases, I will do so as well. I quote from a press release put out yesterday by the Chairman of ATSIC, Gatjil Djerrkura. He said:
The Federal Government and the Australian Democrats have negotiated a number of important concessions for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in negotiations over proposed amendments to the Environment Protection Biodiversity Conservation Bill.
