Federal Environment Minister, Senator Robert Hill and Australian Democrats Leader, Senator Meg Lees and Democrats Environment spokesperson, Senator Lyn Allison, have clearly listened and taken on board key Indigenous concerns about the proposed Bill in a series of meetings with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups, including ATSIC.
This is reflected in a number of key changes they have negotiated to the proposed legislation before the Senate.
We acknowledge that there are a number of Aboriginal groups who would like more time. Indeed, Mr Djerrkura says that he would too; that he would like to see another round of consultations with their constituents before the bill passes into law. We would like that too, but the fact of the matter is that this legisla 
 tion has been around for 18 months; we have had a very extensive inquiry; and I have had meetings with Aboriginal groups both as part of that inquiry and outside there. What remains is that, once Aboriginal people are across the detail, they are—ATSIC tell us—not uncomfortable. I will just run through some of those indigenous benefits.
The objects of the amended bill recognise the role and the knowledge of indigenous peoples in relation to the conservation and sustainable use of Australia's biodiversity. Senator Bolkus cannot claim that any of his legislation has done that. The amended bill explicitly states that it does not affect the operation of native title or Aboriginal land rights legislation. In spite of all of the scaremongering, this bill does not affect native title or Aboriginal land rights legislation.
—You don't know what you've agreed to.
—That has been written into the bill, Senator Bolkus, and you should have a look and acquaint yourself with that fact. In entering into a conservation agreement the minister must take into account obligations under biodiversity convention and the national biodiversity strategy relating to indigenous people's customary use of biodiversity and indigenous knowledge of biodiversity. Again, this is something Labor did not do. The minister must also have regard for the role and interest of indigenous peoples in the conservation of Australia's biodiversity in developing bilateral agreements, recovery plans and threat abatement plans.
Existing provisions relating to indigenous people's rights to use Commonwealth reserves for hunting, food gathering or ceremonial and religious purposes have been reinstated. The Biological Diversity Advisory Committee will now include indigenous representation. So all that Jacky Jacky stuff is nonsense. Our amendments make sure that the voices of indigenous people are heard and that they will have representation on that advisory committee. An indigenous advisory committee will be established to advise the minister on the operation of the act, taking into account the 
 significance of indigenous people's knowledge of the management of land, and the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity.
The appointment of a Northern Territory representative, as you have already indicated, on the boards of Kakadu and Uluru national parks is subject to the consent of traditional owners. Furthermore, there is an opportunity for them to review that appointment and for them to, if necessary, replace that member on the board. So we are not talking here about the Northern Territory taking over control of those two boards of management—nobody has ever suggested that. In fact, as I recall, Senator Bolkus—and I think you were there at the time—a suggestion was put forward by the Kakadu Board of Management that they could live with a Northern Territory member on the board, provided that that statutory role of the National Parks and Wildlife position remained intact.
—And an expansion of the board? What have you done about that? Nothing.
—Indeed, Senator Bolkus, but it is the judgment of indigenous people that they can live with a member of the board. We are not talking about a majority of Northern Territory members; we are talking about somebody who can demonstrate their ability to be cooperative with indigenous people—and that certainly would be my hope. I am persuaded by the government's arguments that, in terms of the future for relations between the boards and the Northern Territory government, there may well be some strong argument for there to be a Northern Territory rep on that board. We have judged, based on what we were told by the Kakadu Board of Management, that this is not the end of the world and that if it is one member it is not going to mean that indigenous people lose control of the board or anything of that sort.
—This is outrageous.
—So your criticisms, Senator Bolkus are really unfounded and, again, I draw your  attention to what Mr Gatjil Djerrkura has said. He has indicated that we have clearly listened—not just slightly listened—and taken on board indigenous 
 concerns. I think for the first time we are going to see legislation which really reflects the important role that indigenous people in this country have in biodiversity.
On the general subject of biodiversity, we have negotiated a range of amendments under this section. I am very proud to say that this country now has the first national biodiversity legislation. We have upgraded the number of categories of threatened species and increased the types of communities listed. We have specified time lines for all the steps of the listing process. We have uncoupled the decision about listing a threatened species from the decision about the feasibility of a threat abatement plan. So that will stop a lot of existing problems where political decisions were used to stop listing threatened species. That listing will be made solely on the basis of scientific criteria. Recovery plans at present are required for only listed species occurring entirely or partly on Commonwealth areas. Now they are required for all listed species and ecological communities as well.
We have registers of critical habitat, deeper safeguards for migratory species than ever before, strict liability in relation to threatened species, and we are banning the capture of dolphins for live display. Anyone who thinks that wild dolphins should be caught and put in a swimming pool for their life is obviously barbaric. Commonwealth fisheries will now be subject to strategic environmental assessment during the next five years. And there has never—I repeat never—been an environmental impact assessment on a Commonwealth fishery. The Democrats see this as a major positive step, with so many fisheries vulnerable to collapse from overexploitation. There will now be conservation agreements entered into for the protection and conservation of biodiversity anywhere in Australia. There will be identification and monitoring of biodiversity and preparation of bioregional plans.
One of the most important agreements we have made with Senator Hill is that there will be a public inquiry into the use of and access to biological resources. Indigenous people will be specifically funded to make submissions and to participate. That will be an open and 
 public inquiry, and it will feed into the regulation making process under this bill. Senator Bolkus will recall that indigenous people have been calling for this kind of inquiry for some long time.
Another important measure is that all wildlife on Commonwealth land will be protected unless it is specifically exempted in a schedule. There will be a regulation making power to list invasive species—again, a first. It is a pity that Senator Bolkus and the Labor Party never thought of this while they were in government. Invasive species, as the Democrats know—Senator Brown probably does not know this—are a major ecological threat, and there are no provisions to deal with them in existing Commonwealth legislation. There is nothing here at present.
This is yet another area in which the Democrats have made a difference and have made sure that this legislation is not only greatly amended from the original version but also a great improvement on the status quo. There are very many other ways in which biodiversity is protected as a result of this bill, and I am proud to say that the Democrats will be part of introducing the very first Commonwealth biodiversity act.

name: Hill, Sen Robert
text:
—I want to build upon the comments I was making before lunch on the indigenous issue. I noted that Senator Bolkus, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, repeated much of what Senator Crossin had said yesterday. It really is the politics of division, I am sad to say. It is an attempt to gain a short-term political advantage through dividing indigenous Australia from non-indigenous Australia, an attempt on Senator Crossin's part to bring the politics of the Northern Territory down here to Canberra to gain, I presume she believes, some short-term political benefit at home. It is a matter of great regret in relation to an issue of such consequence.
I say that because Senator Crossin's contribution yesterday was principally an attack on the Northern Territory government. She cannot win an election in the Northern Territory and so she comes down here with her complaints when rather what she should be 
 doing is addressing the indigenous issues as they relate to the bill. They are very important. The message I wanted to bring and the point I wanted to make—and it really is necessary because unfortunately, in relation to indigenous affairs as in other areas, the Labor Party wants to dwell in the past rather than move forward—
Opposition senators interjecting—
—I am proud of the joint management. I have said that many times publicly and, if we are talking about the Northern Territory parks, in relation to both Kakadu and Uluru.
—Then why change it?
—Senator Crossin said yesterday that the Northern Territory wants to get rid of the indigenous representation on the board. That is wrong. Those they want to get rid of are us: they want to get Canberra out. That is an aspiration I understand from a territory that wishes to be a state. They wish their parks service to play the same role as parks services in the states, and they cannot really see why the Commonwealth still needs to be involved. But they are not against joint management between themselves and indigenous people. Senator Crossin would be aware of the Nitmiluk National Park and of Gurig. There are instances of joint management between indigenous people and the Northern Territory government. When I have visited those parks, particularly Nitmiluk, the indigenous people have told me that it works well.
Be that as it may, we as a Commonwealth government are not going to walk away from either Kakadu or Uluru. We are pleased to be there, playing our part as one of the partners in joint management. We are pleased to bring the best practices in relation to park management and we also recognise the symbolism of those parks in relation to the aspirations of indigenous Australians. But we, in contrast to the Labor Party, also believe that you need to put the wars, battles and disappointments of the past behind and move forward. This idea that one representative of the Northern Territory government—one representative on a board on which it is prescribed that the indigenous people must be a majority—will 
 in some way be a negative is simply a reflection of the disappointments of the past. It is obvious to me—and, I would have thought, to anybody who looked at this issue objectively—that, provided the Northern Territory representative was prepared to contribute in a constructive way, it must be an asset.
—Is that guaranteed in this legislation?
—If Senator Crossin has that assurance, does that mean that she will then support a Northern Territory representative? Of course she will not, because she wants to relive the battles of the past in the Northern Territory. It is a sensible progression in the interests of the parks and of the indigenous people that there be a Northern Territory representative—not, as she asserted yesterday, to give Northern Territory control but to have one Northern Territory representative who can bring the perspective of the Northern Territory government and the Northern Territory parks service. It can help in relation to transfers of staff and the building-up of employment opportunities—all of those things that cooperative relations can achieve.
Senator Crossin says that, because they were not cooperative in the past, they cannot be so in the future. That is a negative, disappointing approach to this issue. What we need—and I would say this to Senator Crossin and to Senator Bolkus, who also seeks to win political points out of these issues—is to move forward. And a Northern Territory representative contributing constructively can be a significant step forward—without any threat, because it is only one representative. I accept that it should be somebody who is satisfactory to the indigenous people.
That is a safeguard but, as we know, traditional owners are influenced by third parties and by people such as Senator Crossin who are much more interested in fighting the political battles than in the advancement of indigenous people. So they are influenced and decisions are not always made on the basis of what is the best outcome, but they get dragged into the political process of the Northern Territory. That is why we have put the provision in that consent will not be unreasonably withheld. Obviously, the person 
 who would be found for these positions would be a person who is sensitive to indigenous issues. This provision will not come into effect for a 12-month period, and there will be no difficulty at all in finding a representative of the Northern Territory government who is sensitive to indigenous issues and can actually work to the betterment and improvement of the parks and of indigenous people who live in those parks. As I have said so many times, they are not just simply parks; they are also communities.
On the same subject, I heard it said yesterday that the government has not consulted. The government has consulted. I have consulted on these issues since this process started in 1996. As I said this morning, I listened to the consultations and I abandoned what I thought would be a good administrative reform by reinstating the position of the director of national parks because that was the request of the indigenous people and of the traditional owners of those two parks. I have watered down the provision and added extra safeguards in relation to the position of a Northern Territory representative so that there can be no threat—and there was never any—or perceived threat. But will the Labor Party acknowledge that? Will Tracker Tilmouth acknowledge that? Of course not. If the Labor Party took Tracker Tilmouth seriously, they would have preselected him. They will not preselect him as a candidate but they come here and want to use his words to support their case.
There are so many other aspects that have been built into this package to ensure a full contribution by indigenous Australia. I want to make particular mention of that which we agreed with ATSIC, that is, to establish an indigenous advisory body. We recognise that indigenous Australians bring to the table a different perspective, a unique perspective, in relation to biodiversity. It is important that that perspective is part of the debate.
—Where is the funding coming from?
—What do you mean `where is the funding coming from'? We will fund it. The government will fund it.
—Environment or ATSIC?
—Environment will fund it.
—Good.
—At least I got some acknowledgment from Senator Bolkus. That committee will ensure at the highest levels at the table an indigenous contribution to this broader environment debate, a contribution that has never been facilitated by such a structure in the past. I would have thought that that would be acknowledged by even the Labor Party. But no: because it would spoil a political point.
There was not within the bill, and I have to acknowledge it was inadvertent, a specific place dedicated on the BDAC committee for an indigenous representative. That has been pointed out and it is now corrected, and it ought to be acknowledged. When I met with the board in Kakadu there were some misgivings about the quorum provisions imposed in the bill. Although I thought they were misconceived, I know they were repeated in submissions made by the Kakadu board and traditional owners to the Senate committee. We have taken steps to amend that so there can be no doubt—in other words, we listened to the indigenous representatives and we acted on their concerns.
Within this bill we have protection for traditional use of land and water in Commonwealth reserves, something that ought to be acknowledged and recognised. We provide for conservation agreements to be entered into with indigenous communities, which is a positive step in the right direction. As was mentioned in the last contribution, there will be a special place for indigenous Australia within the proposed study of access to biological resources because, again, as I said, there is a unique indigenous perspective of these issues and it is important that that perspective is part of the debate.
Consultation requirements have been expanded to address indigenous interests in relation to bilaterals and the recovery plans. That ought to be recognised and it certainly has been by those who take indigenous issues seriously. The objects of the bill have been expanded, also to address indigenous issues. Bilateral agreements will not apply to actions in relation to Kakadu, Uluru and Booderee, 
 contrary, again, to what I recall Senator Crossin saying yesterday. A provision confirms that the bill does not affect the land rights act and the Native Title Act, contrary to what Tracker Tilmouth says in the document to which Senator Bolkus refers. All he has got to do is read the amendments and he would find that what he is asserting in that document is incorrect.
So if you package all of that up, you must concede there have been real steps to ensure that indigenous Australia has a vital place in the whole perspective of how our country manages its natural assets and conserves them to the benefit of future generations. It is in fact an unprecedented opportunity from which all Australians will benefit. Getting full benefit from the Aboriginal perspective is not just to the benefit of Aboriginal Australians but to the benefit of all Australians, and that has been our philosophical approach to this particular act. I hope, as such, that in this year it will be recognised and recalled as a significant contribution to reconciliation as well.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—It is remarkable, is it not, that the patronising can be so glib? The ultimate decision about who is on the boards of these great natural areas, which are indigenous people's areas and which, through their generosity of spirit, they have opened up to all Australians, is now being moved—by sleight of hand endorsed by the Democrats—into the hands of a non-Aboriginal officer appointed by the government. That is where this process has ended up.
I want to briefly talk about biodiversity—because I know Senator Crossin wants to speak on the indigenous issues—and to follow up on what Senator Allison had to say about what a great deal the Democrats have got for biodiversity. Let me start by informing the Senate that half of the biodiversity in Australia—that is, half of the spectrum of wildlife and plant life—is in Australia's forests. We know that wildlife is concentrated in the forests of the world and, because of deforestation primarily, some 50 to 100 species of our fellow creatures on this planet are going to extinction every day.
Here in Australia the count is not kept. For example, in the Tasmanian forests, which are very much affected by this Democrat endorsed bill, there are some 10,000 forest insects. We do not know their role in the forests. We do know by rule of thumb that at least some of these creatures with their ancient lineage will be very important to human health and survival further down the line. But they are not listed, they are not studied and they are not protected.
The Democrats' process today involves endorsing what the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Robert Hill—with his reputation as the worst minister for the environment in this nation's history—has done in the Regional Forest Agreement process, which says that all the unprotected forests of Western Australia, Victoria, Tasmania, New South Wales and Queensland will in future be out of reach of any federal minister. With that goes the wildlife and the plant life, and now with that comes the Democrats' endorsement. Senator Allison gets up and speaks glibly about what she is doing to protect things, but she is selling out half the wildlife species range in Australia in this one fell move.
Not only is she selling it out with her fellow Democrats—in the lap of the government, because they put their place at the Howard table ahead of Australia's biodiversity—but she is saying, `We are going to pass this legislation'—they will vote later today for the third reading—which means that for the next 20 years half the biodiversity of Australia is going to be unprotectable by the minister for the environment, because there is a bilateral agreement in place, unless a state government wants to come to the party. The states will have the control.
What we do know is that in Tasmania the governments are far from taking up that role. In the north-east highlands, beyond Ben Lomond and towards Weldborough—if you can imagine the heart-shaped island of Tasmania, it is in the north-east corner—a forest is being pulverised by the big woodchip companies, with the authority of the Howard government and now with the authority of the Democrats. 
There has been turmoil in those forests, with people risking arrest not least because in the damper, more rainforested part of these highlands there are two species listed as endangered. The Simson stag beetle is a huge, magnificent, glistening forest floor forager. The north-east forest snail, Anoglypta Launcestonensis, is larger than the introduced garden snail with which most Australians are familiar. It is brilliant orange, and it has a magnificent carapace on its back. It is listed as endangered, but the loggers want its territory.
So what has been happening while the minister for the environment and the Democrats bind their hands? Forestry Tasmania has got in a consultant. The consultant said, `Well, yes, this has been listed as vulnerable, endangered and on its way to extinction, but we guess'—because they cannot do better than that—`that if we leave some remnants of this to-be-pulverised forest along rivers and roadsides, which we were going to leave anyway, and we let the bulldozers, chainsaws and firebombers drop incendiaries at the end of the season to burn to death everything in the logged areas, including the north-east forest snail on the endangered list, that's okay.'
Because this snail was getting in the way of logging, they have now gone so far as to move into a process of de-listing, Senator Allison. You do not know about this because you are not aware of the impact on the wellbeing of the biodiversity—the spectrum of wildlife in this country—of handing back power to state governments. We already know from the Regional Forest Agreement—honoured now by the Democrats—that when you hand Commonwealth responsibility for the nation's wildlife, its creatures and its diversity back to state governments, who are under pressure from corporate extractors, the corporate extractors win the day.
So, very early, one creature on the list of threatened and endangered species will simply be removed from the list. It is no longer going to be on the list as endangered because it is no longer going to be allowed to get in the way of the bulldozers, the chainsaws and those people who, at the end of the wrecking 
 of these forest ecosystems in the highlands of north-east Tasmania, come with the firebombers and the 1080—and the same for the rest of this country and the diversity in those forests.
The Democrats today are endorsing the Robert Hill dictum that this embarrassing problem should be handed back to the loggers and the woodchippers. That is what this process is about, and that is why this is such a shameful day—as the Democrats turn their backs on all those years of tub-thumping and saying that they stood for the environment. Today they stand for the chainsaws and the diminution of this nation's environment. The things that Senator Allison read out ought to be part of any decent piece of legislation—but a minor part of it.
What is notable here is how much Senator Allison, when she went to that polished Howard table, failed to get. What is also notable is that Senator Allison—so recently able to march the streets of Melbourne with conservationists for the protection of the forests of East Gippsland—is now endorsing the Regional Forest Agreement which is going to lead to the pulverisation of forests in East Gippsland and the threatening of species in East Gippsland. If you cross the border, breeding koala habitats are marked for destruction under the Regional Forest Agreement endorsed by this bill and about to be endorsed by Senator Allison, Senator Stott Despoja, Senator Woodley, Senator Bartlett, Senator Lees, Senator Murray and Senator Bourne—these new friends of the government environmental wreckers—when they vote yes for this bill on the third reading later today. Let them live with it.

name: Crossin, Sen Trish
text:
—Before I make some comments further to my speech yesterday, I want to say how terrific it is to see some young kids up in the public gallery—and young babies, at that. It is probably one of the very few places in this Parliament House where young children can go, and some of us live in hope for the day we have a child-care centre here that is as large as a gymnasium.
—A bit of relevance to the bill would be helpful, thank you, Senator Crossin.
—We cannot just let these opportunities go by, Madam Chairman. I want to take some arguments through about one particular aspect of this bill, and that is the proposal to change the arrangements for the management of the national parks at Kakadu and at Uluru. I do not want to raise my voice and get angry, but I must say that I am surprised, Senator Allison. Last week we sat together at an inquiry to look at Jabiluka and we met the traditional owners from that area. One of the things that you must not have failed to grasp when we talked to those people is that all of these arrangements—the lease arrangements and the idea of us passing laws in Canberra to change their lifestyle—are very complex issues for them. I have met with these people time and time again, and they have not ruled out having a Northern Territory representative on the board; in fact, they have said they would welcome further discussions and thinking about it. But at this point in time they have said no to that.
One of the things that must have impressed you, as it has impressed me, is that they talk about Aboriginal law being constant. It does not change; it has been with them for many, many years. So if you are going to put changes and suggestions to these people, they need time to think about them and synthesise them. When I put it to them that a Northern Territory government representative on the board may be the way to go, they talked about it and said, `Maybe, but we would want an increase in our Aboriginal representation if that were the case.'
In a letter from the Kakadu Board of Management which was sent on 18 June, they talk about perhaps being serious about having a Northern Territory representative on the board if the Kakadu Board of Management were to have statutory powers to run Kakadu National Park. So those are two suggestions that I have heard traditional owners in this area come forward with. In other words, they are prepared to negotiate and think about changes, but they are not prepared to tolerate people making decisions about the manage 
 ment of the park without their being consulted—and by that I mean consulted in the last five, seven or 10 days—about these amendments. If there is one thing I would urge, Senator Allison, it is that this amendment be withdrawn while you take it back to Aboriginal people, get them to have a look at it, and bring it back in August. If nothing else is achieved today, perhaps this section of the bill could go away for further discussion with the people who matter.
What we are talking about here is an arrangement between people who own the land being leased to the Commonwealth. They have an arrangement as to who is going to control the park. They know who sits on the board of management and they have agreed to that, but it does change. They have not agreed to a change in composition of the board. They have not even had a chance to discuss your amendment or your proposal. The worse thing is that nobody even bothered to make two phone calls to the chairperson at Uluru and the chairperson at Kakadu. When you talk about a Northern Territory representative being on the board unless their consent is unreasonably withheld, what does that mean? Have you taken the time to explain to these traditional owners what those words mean? Even for the sake of this parliament, what does that mean?
Time and time again there have been a number of things that both this government and the Northern Territory government have done, things which Aboriginal people have not agreed with, but they have gone ahead anyway. The government has persisted. So I think at the end of the day the words `unreasonably withheld' will be shown to be meaningless.
Senator Allison quoted a letter from ATSIC. The other thing she should have learnt from talking to Aboriginal people is that they respect the words of the traditional owners. Gatjil Djerrkura and ATSIC do not speak for the traditional owners of Uluru and Kakadu. If you asked Gatjil Djerrkura, he would verify that. He is a traditional owner from north-east Arnhem Land. He cannot make and would not make decisions about Uluru and Kakudu, and 
 I am sure he would support the traditional owners of Uluru and Kakadu in this stance.
Last week, in relation to the Jabiluka approval process, when we asked the traditional owners whether they had been consulted by this government and by this company, Yvonne Margarula said to all of us who were present, `They talked to the traditional owners in this area, but we are the ones who count; we own the land. Other traditional owners disagree with us, but they do agree in our right to say what we want to happen with our land.' If you ask Gatjil Djerrkura whether in fact he upheld the views of the boards of management at Uluru and Kakuda, and ask Mick Alderson and Joanne Willmot for their views, they would support the boards of management. I have no doubt on that. I think this view goes more to a general statement about the bill, as opposed to these specific areas. We have received a couple of letters from Kakadu in only the last 24 hours which talk about either stopping or slowing the process of this legislation. They go on to say:
When the current government came to power, the way of doing business changed in Kakadu and joint management from the inside is now not so good.
From Uluru, in a letter to Meg Lees, those people say:
The traditional owners are asking you and other senators not to agree to amendments to do with their land but to delay the passage of the bill.
They are not saying, `Don't pass it.' What they are saying is, `Delay it.' On behalf of the constituents whom I represent, who have control over these two parks, perhaps what I am saying to you is that this is one area that should just be set aside while you go back and ask them if this is what they want or whether there could be a compromise in order to achieve this. The letter from Uluru goes on to say:
The minister has misled us by initially declaring that the proposed Bill would not affect the joint management arrangements at all.
Senator Hill will say, `There is no change.' In the minds of the traditional owners there is a significant change. First of all, they have not been consulted about these changes in the last week. Secondly, they have an arrangement with the Commonwealth that does not involve 
 a state or territory government representative on the board, and they do not understand the words `unreasonably withheld'. You need time to sit down and talk to the traditional owners about that. They go on further to say:
The bill was then tabled in the House of Representatives before we were aware of its grave implications to existing arrangements.
They also say:
The Minister has not agreed to repeated requests for sufficient time to consult properly and negotiate what amounts to the future of joint management.
I think in this case they are right. They have also raised the fact that they believe there are legal requirements which have not been fulfilled in the process of preparing these new bills. That is not a road which I want to go down, but I do want to impress on people here, particularly on the Democrats and on Senator Hill, that out of the blue we had amendments tabled on Monday night—it does not come as a surprise—where the traditional owners at Kakadu and Uluru know you have been thinking about expanding the membership of the board. They have not ruled it out. They have already put a couple of compromises to you about them having statutory powers to run the park or perhaps increasing their number of representatives. Those compromises are certainly in correspondence that I have received and they are certainly in correspondence that Meg Lees has received—both letters are in front of me.
These people do not want to shut the gate; neither do these people want to be dictated to and told what the new arrangements are. It is not the way they operate, it is not the way they want to operate and it is not the way they should have to operate because they own that land. That area has been disregarded in all of this. It would be like you leasing your house to some person and a third party coming in to sit on your board of management to help you control that lease arrangement. Unless you had been consulted about that, I would have thought you would be pretty annoyed about it.
I am trying to impress on you that there is no urgency about this section of the bill. There is no requirement to get this part of the bill through by midnight tonight. The tradi 
 tional owners of these national parks have put their trust in the Commonwealth and have undertaken a lease with the government to run that park. They are now saying, simply, `You want to change our best practice arrangements and you want to change the way in which the park is managed. You want an additional person on that board, but we have not said yes to that.' Mind you, they have not said no outright either. As well, you have not offered them a complementary person, so you are not going to increase the numbers—
—I did. They rejected it.
—Maybe you need to go back and now put this proposal.
—I did. It went back and back again.
—Have you been back to them, Minister, since these amendments have been tabled? I would say that the answer to that is no. You could not possibly have done that since Monday when these amendments were tabled, or else these letters would reflect otherwise. These people are simply saying, `That's your proposal; let's think about it. Maybe we will reject it outright, but maybe we will sit down and think about it.' These people need time to digest the proposals you are putting. They own this land. I believe these people have the right to be able to sit down and come to a compromise with you. I am astounded that Senator Allison and even Senator Woodley have agreed to such arrangements without even taking that amendment on board and without undertaking to consult with these people about this specific amendment.
There is no rush. You said earlier that there is a year before this will come into place. The boards of management of those national parks have established best practice, and have been internationally recognised for that. I am simply saying that you need to pull this off the agenda. You need to sit down and talk with these people. If it is something they are comfortable with, bring it back in August.

name: Hill, Sen Robert
text:
—There is a lot that could be said in answer to those comments. Firstly, I repeat 
 that there has been consultation for nearly three years. Secondly, a whole range of concessions have been made as a result of those consultations, none of which were acknowledged by Senator Crossin. Thirdly, in relation to the prospect of a new structure for the two parks, perhaps more akin to that of Nitmiluk, which is an interesting precedent, we have said to the Aboriginal people we are prepared to look at that as well.
—Order! It being 4.30 p.m., the time for debate on this section is completed. The question is that government amendment No. 175 on sheet DT218 be agreed to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
—The question is that government amendments Nos 176 to 445 on sheet DT215 be agreed to.

name: Faulkner, Sen John
text:
—Madam Chair, I seek leave for the vote to be taken on amendment No. 180 separately.
—Because you wish to vote in a different manner?
—Yes.
—The question is that amendments Nos 176 to 179 and amendments Nos 181—
—Madam Chair, could you indicate whether leave has been granted for amendment No. 180?
—I am exercising the chair's discretion. You are saying you want to vote differently—
—I actually sought leave in the first instance.
—You do not need leave.
—I understand that.
—So it is Nos 176 to 179 and Nos 181 to 445.
—Can I just check with you: No. 175 has found favour with the committee, I understand.
—Yes.
—Amendments Nos 176 to 445 are before us. I sought leave that amendment No. 180 be taken—
—Be voted on separately.
—Can I seek your guidance on this? I understand that amendments Nos 176 and 177 are related amendments to amendment No. 180. I seek your guidance on that. If so, I would obviously ask that they be dealt with cognately with amendment No. 180. I just seek your guidance on that.
—Certainly. I am unable to tell whether that is apparent from the amendments. Minister, are you able to indicate whether government amendments Nos 176 and 177 are related to government amendment No. 180? Are they consequential or related to one another?
—I am not suggesting they are consequential.
—When I sought guidance this morning, you howled me down.
—The old onion in the hanky again.
—I am seeking your guidance, Madam Chair.
—Well, I am seeking the guidance of the minister because I am unable to ascertain whether there is any relationship or linkage between No. 176 and the others.
—Let me assure you that I am not seeking Senator Hill's guidance, I was seeking yours.
—From the amendments, we are unable to ascertain whether there is any relationship or not.
—I appreciate that with the advice of the Clerk you have attempted to do that. I think it is better for me in the circumstances to seek that amendments Nos 176, 177 and 180 be taken separately. I think that might assist the committee, in the absence of further advice.
—It is Nos 176, 177 and 180 together, and the remainder are Nos 178 to 179 and Nos 181 to 445.

name: Ray, Sen Robert
text:
—I ask that amendment No. 178 be taken separately, please.
—Do you plan to vote a different way?
—Yes, different to all the other clauses that will be before us.
—Okay.

name: Cook, Sen Peter
text:
—Can I ask that amendments Nos 190 to 199 inclusive be put separately, as I wish to vote differently on those matters.
—Two hours of Robert Ray's work and this is the best you can come up with. What a creative lot! How imaginative!

name: Lundy, Sen Kate
text:
—Madam Chair, I ask that amendment No. 196 be dealt with separately, as I would like to indicate I will be voting in a different way.
—Okay.

name: O'Brien, Sen Kerry
text:
—Madam Chair, I ask that amendments No. 192 and Nos 202 to 204 inclusive be put separately, as I wish to vote a different way.
—I hope that this is not spurious.
—This is a stunt that would rival Bob Brown.

name: Cooney, Sen Barney
text:
—Madam Chair, may I ask that amendments Nos 201 to 223 inclusive be taken separately? I want to indicate a different vote.
—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. I don't take offence to much, but to `Pinochet' Hill I do.
—I do not know who—
—I have used it a few times before, but I withdraw it this time.

name: Mackay, Sen Sue
text: —I ask that amendment No. 204 be put separately as I wish to vote differently on this matter.

name: Forshaw, Sen Michael
text:
—Madam Chair, I ask that amend 
 ment No. 361 be taken separately as I wish to vote differently on that matter.

name: Carr, Sen Kim
text: —I ask, Madam Chair, that amendments 360 to 369 inclusive be put separately as I wish to vote differently on these matters.

name: Murphy, Sen Shayne
text: —I ask that amendments 363 and 364 be put separately as I intend to vote differently on those matters.

name: Bishop, Sen Mark
text:
—Madam Chair, I ask that amendments 358 to 361 inclusive and 377 be put separately because I wish to vote differently.
—This is looking very much like a spurious request.

name: Sherry, Sen Nick
text:
—Madam Chair, I could not be more serious. I ask that amendments 375 to 384 inclusive be put separately as I wish to vote differently on these matters.
—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. As I understand it from what was said this morning, this is a practice that has been designed by the chair to facilitate a genuine situation where an individual senator wishes to take a different perspective. It is difficult for me to recall one occasion in the last 18 years in this place on which an individual Labor Party senator decided to take a different position to his or her colleagues. All of a sudden today the Australian Labor Party comes in here and has suddenly adopted a new liberalism.
—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order.
—I am speaking to a point of order.
—Well, you are not making a point of order.
—What's the point of order?
—Make a point of order.
—When I finish, you can have a go.
—Well, you haven't started.
—It is a point of order.
—Minister, what is your point of order?
—Madam Chair, it is that this is a stunt. It is spurious. There is no genuine difference, and you should not let the processes of the Senate be abused in this way. In other words, guidance that has been given to help genuine differences of view should be used for such circumstances, not to facilitate stunts.
—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order on the non-point of order. Of course, that was not a point of order from Senator Hill; it was just an attempt for him to use the guise of the standing orders of taking a point of order to make a speech, which he knows that he cannot do. Another political point: he does not refer to the Senate standing orders or rulings that have been made. I believe, Madam Chair, in this circumstance he ought to have been sat down after the first couple of sentences.
—What is your point of order?
—My point of order, Madam Chair, is that it is a deliberate abuse of the standing orders for Senator Hill to stand up and make that sort of contribution under the guise of a point of order, and he should be sat down immediately.
—There is no point of order. I did not realise that my colleagues had so much choice.

name: Denman, Sen Kay
text: —I ask that amendment 381 be put separately as I wish to vote differently on this matter.

name: Quirke, Sen John
text:
—I ask that amendments Nos 383 and 388 be put separately as I definitely wish to vote differently on this matter.
—I take it you have a running sheet on these, do you?

name: Crossin, Sen Trish
text:
—I ask that amendments Nos 390, 393 and 397 be put separately as I intend to vote differently on those matters.
—I think, given the very large number of motions that people wish to vote separately on—
Opposition senators interjecting—
—I am not arguing about that. It would save time if we went through them seriatim now.

name: McKiernan, Sen James
text: —Madam Chair, I ask that amendments Nos 396 and 399 be put separately as I wish to vote differently on those matters.

name: Hogg, Sen John
text:
—Madam Chair, I wish that amendments Nos 400 to 405 inclusive be put separately because I intend to vote in a different way.
—Before I call Senator Gibbs, given the large number of people who, it would appear, wish to vote different ways on different amendments, I will put them seriatim individually, and if it becomes apparent that people's voting patterns are not according to their wishes and requests that we have seen to date, then I will have to presume that it is a spurious—
—Are you impugning our motives?
—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. I heard your ruling. Could you enlighten the committee further by referring specifically—
Senator Hill interjecting—
Senator Faulkner interjecting—
—Order! Senator Hill and Senator Faulkner, would you please conduct your conversations quietly or some place else, because I cannot hear other senators who are seeking the call.
—Madam Chairman, I raise a point of order on the ruling that I suggest you are foreshadowing. I would ask that you further enlighten the committee by pointing out to the committee under what specific standing order you are going to make that particular ruling.
—Standing order 84(3) gives me the discretion. There are a number of people who have requested variations to the orders because they want to vote differently from previous votes and may wish to 
 change their vote on different amendments. I will now put the amendments individually.
—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 193(3), which states in part:
. . . and all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on those Houses, members or officers shall be considered highly disorderly.
I regard it as highly disorderly to have it suggested that my decision to vote in a particular way on a particular amendment before this committee has somehow an improper motive. I resent that and I believe that any such imputation or suggestion by Senator Hill or anyone else in this committee should be withdrawn.
—No imputation is meant. A significant number of people have indicated that they wish to vote individually and in differing ways on different amendments. However, if, when we start to put those amendments, people vote the same way as others are voting and in a way that would indicate they have changed their minds in respect of what they have requested here, I will be left to draw no other conclusion than—
—Is that imputing on the rest of them?
—No. It relates to the individual.
—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. I wanted to put clearly on the record that I do not wish to vote differently on those ones that have been dealt with previously. My matter of deep conscience relates to amendments Nos 429, 430 and 432. How am I going to indicate that to the chamber if you do not proceed in that way?
—Because I will be putting them separately, Senator, and you will be able to vote on them.
—I see.
—I am now going to put each of the government amendments individually. Be aware of which way you think you are going to vote, please.
—We know.
—That is good. The question is that government amendment No. 176 be—
—Madam Chair, I want to raise a point of order. It is not possible at this stage, now that we are under the guillotine, either for me or for anyone else to move a motion by way of leave. Is it open to the leader to move a motion by leave for the Senate to suspend its committee stages for 20 minutes and then come back and start putting these resolutions? I would indicate that I think leave would be granted if the leader were to seek that.
—If a minister wishes to move a suspension, the minister has the power to do that.
—What happens in relation to the time?
—It will remain in place.

name: Hill, Sen Robert
text:
—It is a novel suggestion, but this government is always cooperative and constructive, and generally trustworthy—
Opposition senators interjecting—
—Trusting—always trustworthy and generally trusting. I want to check a few of the technicalities.
This is an unusual way to do business but, in this new era of flexibility, an alternative option would be that the second environment bill still requires a second reading, and I am sure at least Senator Bob Brown would like to spend 15 minutes bagging us again—notwithstanding that we have heard the speech 20 times already today. If we suspended this consideration whilst the second reading of the second bill, which is the  Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1998 [1999] , took place—I do not know whether the contents of the bill will be relevant to the speech, but anyway—that might facilitate the negotiation that has been suggested. That is put as a suggestion, in somewhat unusual circumstances, to provide a breakthrough.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—We are all committed to the declaration of 
 urgency moved by the government which says that that matter cannot be dealt with until 5 p.m. So that does not help at all.

name: Hill, Sen Robert
text:
—I take it that in the absence of objection, even though we will not hear a speech from Senator Bob Brown, that is accepted as a reasonable way to provide a few minutes break for discussion.
—No, this is your rule.
—The question before the chair would be that government amendment No. 176 be agreed to. Do you wish to move something, Minister?
—I will move whatever process of suspension would be necessary.
—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. It is competent for the minister at the table to move whatever motion he cares to. There was a little hilarity when the minister proposed to move whatever motion was necessary to do whatever he wants to achieve. That may be perfectly reasonable from the point of view of the opposition, but I think you just have to clarify the motion, Minister. That is my point of order. I think there were a couple of guffaws, and it was most ungenerous of my colleagues to go for it in those circumstances, but I understand why they did.
—I am waiting for a motion contrary to the moving of government amendment No. 176.
—It is very difficult to work out whether you have an agreement around here. I will take a chance and move:
That progress be reported.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Ordered that consideration of the bill in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day.

name: Bolkus, Sen Nick
text:
—There are enormous concerns about this Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1998 [1999]  as well as the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998 [1999] . One of the main concerns emanates from the title. We are asked as a Senate to consider the Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1998 [1999] , but that title is something which does not satisfactorily reflect the legislation. Once again we have a bodgying up of the process, once again we have an abuse of the rules and once again we have the government trying to conceal something in this legislation that they should really be more up-front about. Once again we have the Australian Democrats as the conspiratorial joint party to this particular deception.
Let me read what the Parliamentary Library say about this legislation. They make some comments about the legislation and about how this bill is described as a `consequential amendment' bill. They say on page 22 of their report:
The Office of Parliamentary Counsel has advised that although there is no formal limitation on the content or scope of a `consequential amendments' Bill, such a Bill would usually contain provisions required to implement a new legislative scheme and would not normally contain provisions (technical or otherwise) that were unrelated to the scheme's establishment.
This Bill implements a range of necessary amendments that are consequential to the implementation of the EP&BC Bill. However the Bill also makes a range of other amendments which can be interpreted as substantial new proposals which supplement, rather than arise from, the EP&BC Bill. This raises issues as to the adequacy of consultation and scrutiny of these substantive measures by all relevant stakeholders. On that point, it is notable that the current Bill was not included in the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee's inquiry into the EP&BC Bill 1998 until 24 March 1999. The Committee reported on 27 April 1999.
They are the two primary concerns. First of all, you have misdescription. You have this legislation described as `consequential' when in essence it is more than consequential. In essence it raises other measures that are of 
 enormous relevance and importance to stakeholders but about which those stakeholders have not had the normal advance notice. More importantly, this bill was sent to the committee late in the process—only three or four weeks before the committee reported.
These are not minor amendments. They are also reflective of how this legislation has been handled by this government and this parliament. We have had amendments introduced to the major bill and amendments to the consequential bill. Those amendments have been discussed in secret but, in respect of this bill as well as the other, we have not had engagement with industry or with the states, I must say—and the states have an enormous stake in the management of operations under these two bills—and, extremely importantly in respect of this particular consequential provisions bill, we have had no engagement with indigenous Australians. We are not talking about inconsequential amendments; we are talking about consequential amendments. Yesterday Senator Hill said that, if we were serious, we would have given him notice in respect of certain matters before we came in here yesterday.
Well, if he were serious in respect of this legislation, he would have given us—this parliament—notice as to his amendments before we came in yesterday. So, once again, this legislation is in the same category as the major piece of legislation—that is, there are amendments to it; amendments which have avoided public scrutiny and which have not had sufficient parliamentary scrutiny as well. When you are looking at the process, something like 20 seconds per amendment is totally inadequate parliamentary scrutiny.
The best assessment of this legislation also comes from the library's Bills Digest. What does this legislation do? It does exactly the sorts of things that we have been talking about for some little while in this place. It affects indigenous people's interest in, stake in and rights on the boards of management of the Kakadu National Park, the Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park and the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community council. It appears that, although these issues were raised in the 1998 consultation paper, it was not indicated 
 in the central aspects of the act that changes would be made. So you had indigenous Australians having to take last-minute mercy dashes to appear before the committee to try and defend their positions as to joint management and their concern in respect of the abolition of the position of the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. That is something that we are told has been wound back, but we have not been told the details of that. There were concerns in respect of what they thought would be a compulsory transfer of the lease from the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service to the Commonwealth.
These matters in themselves are important matters, not consequential on the other legislation, but they were thrown in here primarily, I suppose, because the government was thinking that we would believe it was an after-thought, but they were thrown in here in a way that did not give stakeholders sufficient notice. The concept of the addition of a Northern Territory board member also arises in this consequential legislation. This legislation also affects the traditional use of land and water by Aboriginals. Section 70 provides, in essence, a limitation of rights to those appearing in the current legislation, so we do have some concerns in respect of indigenous Australians.
We also have concerns as to what this particular legislation does to the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. Not having done enough damage in their primary legislation, the government then seeks to amend the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. The Council of Australian Governments' 1997 heads of agreement provides the policy basis for the proposed EPBC act. It states that the Commonwealth and state heritage ministers would develop a cooperative national heritage protection strategy. The government's environment reform 1998 consultation paper proposed the introduction of a new heritage protection law at a date following the debate on the primary legislation.
This new heritage legislation has not been introduced in the parliament. Given this, we would deem it inappropriate to remove the links between the Commonwealth environ 
 ment minister and the Australian Heritage Commission in relation to actions that may impact on heritage areas. In order to avoid the creation of a regulatory vacuum on these issues, it may be—and we will be moving amendments to this effect—advisable to continue the operation of the EP(IP) Act in relation to heritage matters until a new heritage regime is introduced.
We should save the operation of the Heritage Commission Act—our amendments will go to that. But, given the conduct of proceedings in the last 24 hours or so, there is absolutely no way that those substantive amendments will get up. We might get some mealy-mouthed alternative from the Democrats, we may get some promise of a committee or an inquiry down the track—all those sorts of things—but the substantive operation of the Australian Heritage Commission will be affected by this legislation, as will the operation of the world heritage protection act itself. We have in the government's legislation some incremental improvement in respect of the protection of world heritage areas but we also have some monumental wind-back from the currently prevailing law, and we are also seeking to protect those provisions that are about to be affected.
There are other aspects. There are amendments to the Lands Acquisition Act and there is the repeal of the Biological Control Act 1984, all under the guise of consequential amendments. So we say the government stands condemned because this is not a consequential amendments bill; this does much more than that. We say the government and the Democrats stand condemned because they have entered into an arrangement which does over some substantive rights and some pretty substantial protections in terms of indigenous Australians, world heritage and the AHC. We also say they stand condemned because no-one in here, let alone anyone outside of here, has had enough opportunity to give this legislation adequate scrutiny.

name: Brown, Sen Bob
text:
—The previous speaker in this debate on the Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1998 [1999]  was absolutely right. Not only are we in the position where we are 
 dealing with a bill which claims to be consequential on the major environment bill that has been debated for much of the day, but also we have been asked by the government to deal with this bill before that environment bill has gone through and before we even know how it is going to be amended. That is an extraordinary situation for the Senate to find itself in. It shows that the government and the Democrats are in a complete mess as far as the handling of this environment legislation is concerned. They do not know what their strategy is. They did bring in the guillotine. They thought that was the end of it and that all this stuff would be finished by half past five this evening, but now they are in a complete mess because people on this side of the house who think differently from the Democrats and the government about the environment have wanted the debate to go on.
Let me just take up what Senator Bolkus said a moment ago about the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. The Australian Heritage Commission was established in the wake of the flooding of Lake Pedder in 1972. There was a national parliamentary inquiry into that disaster by the then Whitlam government in 1974. That inquiry found that never again should the Commonwealth be in the position of not intervening on the loss of heritage of national significance, that such places ought to be listed and that there ought to be a facility for warning the federal government when such heritage, be it natural heritage or cultural heritage, was at risk. As a result of that, the Australian Heritage Commission was established in 1975.
The commission has had a major role in the defence of Australia's environment since then, even though in the last decade successive governments have tried to wind down its influence and power. I am very well aware that the Heritage Commission was central to the saving of the Franklin River. The Australian Democrats claim a role in that but their role pales into insignificance when compared with the active role of the Australian Heritage Commission at the time. In fact, the Australian Heritage Commission was so active at that stage in alerting politicians and the public to the threats to the Franklin River that no doubt 
 in the collective political memory that was a reason for it being put under strangulating political repression in the years that have followed.
The legislation that the Democrats and the government are railroading through the chamber today—we will get back onto that later at the committee stage—effectively gets rid of the Australian Heritage Commission and its relevance. But the agreement between the states and the Commonwealth has been that, instead of having the Heritage Commission, there be a joint arrangement. Let me outline how that arrangement would go. Following the meeting of the Council of Australian Government heads in 1997—that is, the state and federal heads—there was an agreement for the Commonwealth and state heritage ministers to develop a cooperative national heritage strategy. Let me interpret that. The arrangement was to get rid of the functions of the Australian Heritage Commission and replace it with ecowaffle—a passing of the buck between Commonwealth and state heritage ministers—which was going to do nothing in particular to protect heritage in the way the 1975 establishment of the Australian Heritage Commission was meant to do.
The government's environment reform 1998 consultation paper proposed the introduction of a new heritage protection law following the environment bill which the Democrats are pushing through this place today at the behest of the government. This new heritage bill would be the replacement, essentially, for the Australian Heritage Commission and its past good works. But we do not have such a bill. Here we have legislation effectively getting rid of the Australian Heritage Commission on the promise that there will be a Commonwealth-state arrangement to replace it, but there is no replacement. We have a vacuum of that function. It has been abolished. We are back to the flooding of Lake Pedder, thanks to the Democrats supporting the government on this matter.
We are being asked to support what is called a consequential bill which is nothing of the sort. It is a bill to abolish the Australian Heritage Commission's powers and replace them with nothing at all. I will not be part of 
 that. The Democrats, of course, will be, because they do not even understand what is in this consequential bill. They are more interested in their moment of power at the Howard table of power. They are more interested in selling out any environmental principle that will get in the way of them keeping that seat at the table. They are more interested in trying to put a gloss on the environmental disaster that they are delivering through this parliament to the people of Australia in these terrible days for the environment. If an arrangement has been made between the states and the Commonwealth to look after matters of national heritage importance—if this cooperative national strategy has been established—I ask Senator Woodley, who is the only Democrat in the chamber, to get up and explain what it is.
—You are the only Green.
—Senator Abetz intervenes from the other side of the chamber, but he does not know either. We could ask him to get up and explain this alternative that we are supposed to accept as coming into place which is not mentioned anywhere in the bill. It is a wing and a prayer, or at least a promise that we are supposed to accept coming from the chainsaw driven offices of the minister for the environment or, as we now have it, the subservient hand on the chainsaw gang of Democrat senators who have sold out so comprehensively on the environment these last few days. I know that no Democrat will explain to the Senate what they are doing, for the simple reason that they do not know. They have abrogated their policies; they have dumped their policies. In the vacuum that that leaves, they are simply reliant on Howard government environmental policies. That is the measure of their strength of commitment to the environment these days.
The Democrats are prepared to guillotine this bill but they do not have the foggiest about how to explain why we should be voting for a situation where the Australian Heritage Commission goes west and the promised replacement is nowhere to be seen. We are in this extraordinary situation on another matter—biological control. We are being asked to deal with legislation which 
 gets rid of the effects of the Biological Control Act 1984 because they are no longer appropriate, but we have not yet dealt with those amendments to the environment protection bill. We have this extraordinary situation, this remarkable failure of process by the Democrats. There is not even a Democrat adviser in the place. They have fled altogether to try to work out what this bill is about, because they were not ready for it.
They were depending on the so-called environment protection bill—I would call it the environment wreckage bill—being passed. It has not been passed because they have been outmanoeuvred this afternoon by the people on this side of the chamber. The guillotine was not dropped on debate on that important environment legislation at 5 o'clock because, despite the combined brains of the government and the Democrats, they still did not see what was coming and they were outmanoeuvred. That outmanoeuvring means that the environment protection bill has not gone through. We do not know what the outcome is going to be, but here are the Democrats asking us to abolish the biological control provisions which the Commonwealth currently has in place. They have not replaced them with anything. They talk about how they want biodiversity protected in this country, but they are getting rid of control mechanisms and so far they have put nothing else in their place.
That is why they are such environmental puppies. As I said yesterday, they have rushed around the room barking at everybody and then jumped onto the first lap available. They are political poodles. Of course, the first lap available was Senator Hill's. Last week on the GST it was the Prime Minister's, with room also on Mr Costello's. But the Democrats do not know what they are doing, except for this: they do know that there is an open door at the end of the green carpeted corridor, on the occasions when it suits the government, where they can sit and feel important. And they will trash any policy to keep that door open and they have trashed many a policy in the last few days. We have this extraordinary situation where, having got rid of protection mechanisms which have been developed over recent 
 decades, as of this moment they have nothing to replace them with.
We do not know whether or not the amendments to the environment protection bill are going to go through. We have no way of knowing that. It would be quite irresponsible of us to deal with this so-called consequential bill which abolishes the existing protection for the environment until we know what is going to happen with the major bill, which the Democrats are supporting the government to get through. That is the extraordinary tangle we have got into. Maybe it is worth recalling that time-honoured quote:
Oh what a tangled web we weave when first we practise to deceive.
The Democrats have practised to deceive those people who voted for them—the environmentalists; a million Australians who thought that they would stand by the environment; people all across this country who thought that the Democrats' record would be good. Can you imagine what would have happened to the Democrats if their sell out over the last fortnight on their social and environmental principles had been known to the electorate last October? They would have been decimated. I have to admit to being one of the millions of Australians who is gobsmacked by the way in which they have dropped every founding principle of the party to get to the table of power. That is what they have done, but I am not going to be one who supports this piece of legislation and leaves a vacuum. There may be a vacuum of Democrat policy; there is now a vacuum of Democrat principle.
There is now a failure to understand the almighty consequences of what they have done by Senator Lees, Senator Stott Despoja, Senator Bourne from New South Wales, Senator Woodley and Senator Bartlett from Queensland, and Senator Murray from Western Australia. There is a vacuum of appreciation of what they have done, but they are sticking with it because they want to be counted as one of the big players. As one of those senators said to a business lunch, as reported in the national media a couple of weeks ago, they are flushed not only with the new sense of power but also with the prospect 
 now of getting some of the kick-backs—that is, donations—that come from the corporate sector when you do the right thing, as far as vested interests are concerned in this place. The Democrats are moving from being a party of the people and the environment to being creatures of the big end of town. That is what this is all about.
However, when such revolutions in process occur, there are glitches and one is occurring right now. I note that Senator Lees has come into the chamber and therefore I expect that we are going to have a clearing of the air by Senator Lees as to what has happened to the Australian Heritage Commission's powers; why there is no replacement; and why she is asking the Senate to effectively abolish the powers of the Australian Heritage Commission and replace them with nothing else at this particular juncture on this Wednesday afternoon in June 1999.

name: Abetz, Sen Eric
text:
—We have just listened for about 20 minutes to an assault on the Australian Democrats by the sole Tasmanian Green in this chamber. The reason that he had to devote all that time to assaulting the Australian Democrats is that it is quite clear he has not read the bill. He has not considered its provisions so he has embarked on an attack of the Democrats. But I would just kindly remind him that, on page 11 of the explanatory memorandum, he might find some of the answers to the questions that he posed in a rhetorical way. If he had spent more time studying the legislation and the explanatory memorandum, he might have been in a position of not having to devote so much of his 20 minutes to a wholesale assault on the Australian Democrats.
The bill that we are considering is the  Environmental Reform (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1998 [1999] . This bill continues the process of Commonwealth environmental legislation. Labor and the Greens used to talk big about the environment, but they failed to deliver. What they cannot abide is the fact that, since the Howard government was elected, there has been a program of environmental reform in this country not witnessed 
 before. Of course, the Natural Heritage Trust is one of the examples of environmental reform in this country. It has delivered millions of dollars for repair to the environment—a project never thought of by Labor or the Greens but one that we were able to do because we were willing to forgo the public ownership of Telstra to ensure that something more important remained within our grasp; that is, the environment of this country. So the Natural Heritage Trust is part of our environment reform program, as is the Green Corps—a fantastic program that has delivered environmental repair throughout the breadth of this nation.
But has Senator Brown acknowledged the wonderful work of the Natural Heritage Trust? Does he acknowledge the wonderful work of all those volunteers in the Green Corps, who actually do something for the environment? Absolutely not. Senator Brown locks himself away in his rooms and dreams up these speeches. I have to say that I think the dreaming has lapsed somewhat of late because it is the same speech repeated time and time again. It is becoming a bit boring. All we ever get to hear about is a chainsaw. In fact, he is starting to sound like a chainsaw—that repetitive buzz and the noise do not make much sense, except in Senator Brown's mind; most of his contributions these days are not to build up but to destroy.
We have the Natural Heritage Trust and we have the Green Corps program. What else have we done for the environment? We have the wonderful Regional Forest Agreement that, for the first time in this country's history, has balanced conservation and the needs of the forest communities who get a living from the forests. Let us not forget that what we harvest from the forests is in fact a renewable resource. If you do not have the timber harvesting, what do you have? I suppose you have mining for building products instead—products which are not renewable. So the timber industry is vital.
—You still have mining products for building that are not renewable, but you need them.
—Sorry, Senator Murphy? You are not making sense again—a bit like 
 your contributions with Premier Jim Bacon. The regional forest agreements have been another wonderful example of this federal government getting to terms with the environmental problems of this nation and making a contribution in a way that will have lasting benefit. On top of that wonderful record, we now have this legislation and the bill that was just before us.
This bill has three primary objectives. Firstly, it will provide for the repeal of the five acts to be replaced by the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998 [1999] . Those acts are: the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974; the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975; the Whale Protection Act 1980; the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983; and the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992. It makes sense to have this reform of environmental legislation. Secondly, the bill puts in place savings and arrangements for a smooth transition from the processes that are in place under the existing acts, including environmental assessment and permitting arrangements to the new schemes established under the  Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998 [1999] .
Thirdly, the bill also amends Commonwealth government legislation that is affected either by the repeal of the five acts or by the content of the proposed  Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998 [1999] . This bill, together with the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Bill 1998, provides a new environmental law regime which enables the Commonwealth to join with the states in providing a truly national scheme of environmental protection and biodiversity conservation, recognising our responsibility to not only this but also future generations.
What this legislation is about is trying to ensure that we as a federation cooperate with the states on environmental issues, rather than taking the sledgehammer approach like Senator Brown, who could not win the debates in his home state of Tasmania and therefore had to seek federal intervention to win them. We say that, instead of having that `them and us' approach to environmental 
 issues, it makes a lot more sense to cooperate with the states and ensure that we are able to work in a responsible, user-friendly way to deliver benefits to the environment and, as a result, to future generations.
—Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. I therefore put the question that the bill now be read a second time.
	 Question put.

name: O'Brien, Sen Kerry
text: —by leave—In relation to the statement I made seeking to have certain  parts of the bill moved separately, I have now been persuaded to reconsider my position. My colleagues have also been persuaded, given the forceful position put to us in the intervening period; that is, my colleagues and I will not be seeking to have the clauses dealt with in the way suggested earlier.

name: Hill, Sen Robert
text:
—by leave—It should be unnecessary to say it, but the coalition will of course be reasonable in relation to opposition amendments, if the opposition wishes to put them in a number of groups.
—I now proceed to chapter 5, government amendments 176 to 445. The question is that the following amendments be agreed to:
(176)	 Clause 176, page 160 (line 22), omit "may", substitute "must".
(177)	 Clause 181, page 164 (lines 3 to 7), omit subclause (3), substitute:
	 (3)	 The list, as first established, must contain only the ecological communities listed in Schedule 2 to the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992  immediately before the commencement of this Act, and they must be listed in the endangered category. 

(178)	 Clause 185, page 166 (after line 25), at the end of the clause, add:
	 (2)	 The Minister must decide whether to amend the list referred to in section 181 to include an ecological community that is described as critically endangered, endangered or vulnerable in a list that is:
		 (a)	 kept by:
			 (i)	 a State; or
			 (ii)	 a self-governing Territory; or
			 (iii)	 the body known as the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council; and
		 (b)	 identified by the Minister by a notice published in the Gazette .
(179)	 Clause 188, page 169 (lines 9 and 10), omit "species included in the conservation dependent category", substitute "conservation dependent species".
(180)	 Clause 188, page 169 (lines 12 to 14), omit all the words from and including "and" (first occurring) to the end of subclause (4).
(181)	 Clause 188, page 169 (lines 15 to 24), omit subclauses (5) and (6).
(182)	 Clause 189, page 170 (line 8), omit "or ecological community", substitute ", ecological community or threatening process".
(183)	 Clause 191, page 171 (lines 15 and 16), omit subclause (2), substitute:
	 (2)	 The Minister must forward a nomination to the Scientific Committee within 10 business days of receiving the nomination. However, the Minister need not forward a nomination that the Minister rejects under subsection (6).
(184)	 Clause 191, page 172 (lines 6 to 15), omit subclause (6), substitute:
	 (6)	 The Minister may reject a nomination if satisfied that it is vexatious, frivolous or not made in good faith.

(185)	 Clause 196, page 173 (line 17) to page 174 (line 13), omit the clause, substitute:
